english: When I arrived home food is already prepared for supper.

english: Then the sun came out and said to them, "Don't quarrel; you are equal in importance."

english: "If there is no fire, it is without meaning." "If there is no water, it is without meaning."

english: "Be reconciled and help one another," the sun said to them.

ami: O pikomod ni Cay-Eng-Wen Cong-tong a mita'ong to Yin-co-min-co a tilid.
english: President Tsai Ing-wen's Apology to the Indigenous Peoples on Behalf of the Government.

ami: I 'a'ayaw no 22 a mihecaan no nini a romi'ad i, mafalicto a matongal ko rikec no mita to "San-paw" sanay a tilid i, "Yin-co-min" hanto ko pipangangan. Onini i, o palasawaday to misawili'ay misakakinihay konini a ngangan, ato pasifana'ay a pahapinang ao "Tapang no Taywan a tamdaw ko Yin-co-min-co" sanay. Itini tona parenaan a tomireng, ta manga'ay mi'awas kita a tala 'a'ayaw anini. Komod han no mako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to polong no Yin-co-min-co, a paini to ngodo^ no faloco' no niyam. 400 a mihcaan to ko pades ato masakakinih ko polong namo, na onian saka Komod a han no mako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong kamo.
english: On this day 22 years ago, the term "shanbao" (mountain people) in the Additional Articles of our Constitution was replaced with the proper name: "indigenous people". This correction not only did away with a discriminatory term, but also highlighted the status of indigenous peoples as Taiwan's "original owners". From this basis, today, we are taking another step forward. To all indigenous peoples of Taiwan: On behalf of the government, I express to you our deepest apology. For the four centuries of pain and mistreatment you have endured, I apologize to you on behalf of the government.

ami: Paso'elin kako, tangasa anini i, taliyok no 'orip ako i, iray ho ko hamaan a ta'ongen sanay a tamdaw. Onini ko satadamaanay a demak no mako anini a komod to Cen- fo a mita'ong. Oya palanga'ayay sanay to misakakinihay a demak, ano ca o heci no saka comahad no tamdamdaw ko roray pades no finacahan sanay a haharatengen i'ayaw i, o sasafaloco'en no mako anini a mifalic, inian ko sa'ayaway a haharatengen.
english: I know that even now, there are some around us who see no need to apologize. But that is the most important reason why I am representing the government to issue this apology today. To see what was unfair in the past as a matter of course, or to treat the pain of other ethnic peoples as an unavoidable part of human development, this is the first mindset that we, standing here today, resolve to change and overturn.

ami: Sakameden ako ko sowal a paini, nawiro mita'ong kako to Yin-co-min-co. Onini a pala^ i Taywan i, 'ayaw no 400 a mihcaan iraayto ko maro'ay a tamdaw. O nangra sa a fana' a ma'orip, iraay ko sowal, serangawan, lekakawa no 'orip ato saliyoh no 'orip. Nikawrira, ira ko nai papotalay onini a pala^ a tamdaw a midefongay.
english: Let me put in simple terms why we are apologizing to the indigenous peoples. Four hundred years ago, there were already people living in Taiwan. These first inhabitants lived their lives and had their own languages, cultures, customs, and domains. But then, without their consent, another group of people arrived on these shores, and in the course of history, took everything from the first inhabitants who, on the land they have known most intimately, became displaced, foreign, non-mainstream, and marginalized.

ami: Talacowa ona irikoray a tahini a tamdaw ko saka molahad no saway, nikawrira, onini a tamdaw ko milifokay to saka'orip no i'ayaway a maro' a tamdaw. Lasawad sato caira i kananaman naira a pala^, matiya sato o palafangay, caayto ko tanosok, malacofocofokay to ko 'orip. O pades no roma a finacadan ko saka cipoc no mikowanay. O a'imeren koni a saway, papainien ko so'linay a demak a pangiha'. O tadamaanay a sasafaloco'en no Cen-fo koni a demak, onianay saka tomireng kako anini a mita'ong. Ano caay kahatira i, o caayay ko mo^celay a kitakit ko kitakit no mita.
english: The success of one ethnic people can be built on the suffering of another. Unless we deny that we are a country of justice, we must face up to this history. We must tell the truth. And then, most importantly, the government must genuinely reflect on this past. This is why I stand here today.

ami: Ira ko cecay " O sawayan no Taywan tong se " sanay a codad. Sowal sa i pali'ayaw a sowal " Awaay ko saway no Taywan. O Olanda^ ko militapangay, ci Cen Cen-kong ko midemakay, o Cin-tay ko parafaray" sa ko sowal , o no payrang a harateng koni. Nawhani, i'ayaw no pinapina a patek a mihcaan i, iraa:yto ko Yin-co-min-co a fanacadan toni a pala^. O kadofahay a serangawan ato taneng i marayraya:y to itini. Orasaka, komod han no mako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Yin-co-min-co.
english: There is a book called "The General History of Taiwan" published in 1920. In its foreword are these words: "Taiwan had no history. The Dutch pioneered it, the Koxinga Kingdom built it, and the Qing Empire managed it." This is a typical Han view of history. The truth is that indigenous peoples have been here for thousands of years, with rich culture and wisdom that have been passed down through generations. But we only know to write history from the perspective of the dominant. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

ami: O pipatay pi'afas no Olanda ato ni Cen Cen-kong to 'orip no Tangafolan; piri'ang no Cing-caw ato pisapangcah no Ripon a nikowan, tangasa i lotokay enaray sanay a pikowan no Min-kok. O tayniay i Taywan a mikowanay tina 400 a mihcaan i, sahto o sala'is ko sapi'afas ato sapiri'ang to saka 'orip no Yin co-min-co. Orasaka, komod han ako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Yin-co-min-co.
english: The Dutch and the Koxinga Kingdom massacred and exploited the Pingpu ethnic group. The Qing Empire presided over bloody confrontations and suppression. Colonial Japan put in place comprehensive savage policies. And the post- war ROC government undertook assimilation policies. For 400 years, every regime that has come to Taiwan has brutally violated the rights of indigenous peoples through armed invasion and land seizure. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

ami: Pakayni i nanaman no 'orip no Yin-co- min-co ato taneng no to'as ko saka saysay, saka nga'ay no niyaro' ato taliyokay a pinalengaw. Nikawrira, yo mapatireng no aniniay a Kitakit ko sapihalaka to niyaro' a demak i, mapalasawad to ko lekakawa ato pakoniyaniyah a 'imar no Yin-co-min-co. Mapalasawad ko yofayof ato caayto ko mamahayda ko salongoc no 'orip. Orasaka, kotay han ako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Yin-co-minco.
english: Indigenous peoples maintain tribal order according to traditional customs, and ecological balance according to traditional wisdom. But in the process of modern state-building, indigenous peoples lost the right to steer their own course and govern their own affairs. The fabric of traditional societies was torn apart, and the collective rights of peoples were not recognized. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

ami: Na iraay ko sowal no Yin-co-min-co, yo o Ripon ko nikowanay i, macengel a pala no Riponen ko lekakawa, o roma sato, ikor no 1945 a micaan i, palasawaden no Cen-fo ko sowal, caay ka nga'ay a somowal to sowal no tireng, saka lasawad sa ko sowal no Yin-co-min-co ato no Tangafolan. To hatiniay mikowanay a Cen-fo, caay kaedeng ko pidipot to saka rayrayaw no serangawan no Yin- co-min-co, Orasaka, komod han ako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Yin-co-min-co.
english: Indigenous peoples had their own languages. However, with Japanese rule aiming to assimilate and turn all into imperial subjects, and with the ROC government banning tribal languages after 1945, indigenous peoples' languages suffered great losses. Most Pingpu languages have disappeared. Successive governments have been negligent in the protection of indigenous cultures. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

ami: Toya mihcaan, yo mafokil ko Fotod a tamdaw i, liapa^ han no Cen-fo a midokdok mi'tli i Fotod ko cisawarakay a 'afo no he-neng. Oni ko saka makari'ang ko 'orip no i Fotoday a tamdaw. Orasaka, komod han no mako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Yin-co- minco.
english: Without the knowledge of the Yami tribe, the government stored nuclear waste on Orchid Island. Tribe members on the island had to suffer the negative consequences. For this, I apologize to the Yami people on behalf of the government.

ami: Yo midefong i Taywan ko sapapotalay a tamdaw i, sa'ayaway a makari'ang i, oya maro'ay i no^etipan a dafdaf a Tangafolan a finacadan. Oya madado^do^ay a mikowanay ko palasawaday to Tangafolan a finacadan. Orasaka, komod han no mako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Tangafolan a finacadan.
english: Ever since outsiders began arriving in Taiwan, the Pingpu ethnic group on the western plains have born the brunt of the impact. One ruling power after another eroded the individual and collective identities of the Pingpu ethnic group. For this, I apologize to the Pingpu ethnic group on behalf of the government.

ami: Irikor no pipasasiyor to pikowan i, na irato ko pipaca'of no Kitakit to salongoc no Yin-co-min-co. Mihayda ato misa'icel ko Cen-fo a midemak tonian. Mapasadakay to no mita ko "paranaan a rikec no Yin-co-min-co" nika onini a rikec i, caay ka lalen ko yofayof no Cen- fo a milayap. Caay ka narikay kasolinga' ato caay ka ha^emin ko midemakan no niyam. Orasaka, komod han no mako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Yin-co-min-co.
english: After the democratic transition, the country began to respond to the appeals of indigenous movements. The government made certain promises and efforts. Today, we have an Indigenous Peoples Basic Law that is quite advanced. However, government agencies have not given sufficient weight to this law. Our actions have not been fast enough, comprehensive enough or sound enough. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

ami: Malita'ang ko Taywan to "adihayay a kasasiroma no serangawan" sanay. Nikawrira, o sakatanektek no tireng, sapasifana', saki'orip, sapikowan a kalodemak i, irarem ho no roma a finacadan. O roma sato, caay ka lasawad ko pisakakinih to Yin-co-min-co. Caay ka solinga' no Cen-fo konini a demak, saka mapakaroray ko Yin-co-min-co. Orasaka, komod han no mako ko Cen-fo a mita'ong to Yin-co-min-co.
english: Taiwan is known as a culturally diverse society. But even today, indicators on health, education, economic livelihood, political participation and more still show gaps between indigenous and non- indigenous peoples. Meanwhile, stereotypes and even discrimination against indigenous peoples have not gone away. The government has not done enough, so indigenous peoples have suffered pain and frustration unknown to other ethnic peoples. For this, I apologize to the indigenous peoples on behalf of the government.

ami: Caay ka tatodong ko pisa'icel no niyam, to kasarayray, o saka hatini namo a mapades tahanini i, o nikaca kanarikay no niyam a pakahapinang to rarima no namo, orasaka, maanen aca haw. O pita'ong anini, talacowa maapacay to, nika o litapang koni. 400 a mihcaan o roray ato pades no Yin-co-min-co i, caay ka nga'ay pakayni i cecay a tilid ato pita'ong a malahdaw sanay ko pinanay no mako. Nikawrira, so'linay ko hinatala no mako, o nipita'ong anini i, i laloma'ay ho nonini a kitakit a tamdaw i, pasayraen i kasasisolol ko litapang ko nga'ay.
english: Our efforts have fallen short, and succeeding generations have been blind to this inadequacy. Because of this, your hardship has continued to this day. For this we are truly sorry. Today's apology is long overdue, but it is a beginning. I do not expect any one speech or phrase of apology to wipe away four centuries of pain and suffering by the indigenous peoples. But I do hope with all my heart that today's apology will set this country and all its people on the path towards reconciliation.

ami: Pakaynien ako i cecay a taneng no Yin- co-min-co, a pasowal to demak anini. I sowal no Tayal "so'linay a demak" sanay i, "Balay" han. "kasasisolol" sanay i "Sbalay" han, 'ayaw no "Balay" a tilid tongal han to "s" a tilid i, "so'lin a demak" ato "kasasisolol" a sowal i makakafitay sanay. Ano pahci^ han ko sowal i, so'linay a kasasisolol i, deng so'linen ko faloco' a masaso'ayaw ta malahci ko demak.
english: Please allow me to shed light on this occasion with a piece of indigenous wisdom. In the Atayal language, truth is called "Balay", and reconciliation is called "Sbalay", so you simply add an "S" sound to "Balay". Truth and reconciliation are in fact two related concepts. In other words, only by facing the truth sincerely can reconciliation be attained.

ami: I serangawan no Yin-co-min-co, ano ira ko pararaway to cima a tamdaw , ano mangalay a masasisolol i, palisaoten no mato'asay ko miri'angay ato makari'angay a tamdaw. Masa'opo^ caira i, caay ko nika pita'ong a cecay, alapasadak caira to nai faloco'ay a sowal. Yo maherek a paini to so'linay a rayray no demak i, ta: han no mato'asay a matatakid, mata'lifayto a demak i ta'lif hato. Onian koya "Sbalay" sanay.
english: In indigenous cultures, when a tribe member has offended another and intends to reconcile, an elder brings together the offender and the offended – not to produce a direct apology, but to allow each side to frankly share their inner journeys. When this truth-telling concludes, the elder calls for everyone to drink together, so that what is past is truly past. This is "Sbalay".

ami: Hinatala kako anini tona sa'opo^, o Cen- fo ato Yin-co-min-co i, masasi Sbalay. Oya moraraway ato so'linay a rayray no demak i 'ayaw i, hacecay a han no mako a patalahekal. Ano honi, a ira ko Yin-co- min-co a salikaka paini to nafaloco'an niira. Mangodo kako a milongoc to sapisololaw namo, nikawrira, milongoc kako i tamowanan, o mararaway i'ayaw i caay to piliyaw, ira ho ko cecay a romi'ad konini a Kitakit i, pasayraen i kasasisolol karari'ari'ay ko nga'ay.
english: I hope today's occasion can be a "Sbalay" between the government and the indigenous peoples. I have spoken of past mistakes and truths the best I can, with nothing held back. In a moment, our indigenous friends will speak. I do not dare ask you to forgive, here and now. But I sincerely ask you to sustain the hope that past wrongs will not be repeated, and that one day, this country can see true reconciliation.

ami: O litapang konini, malaheciay ko kasasisolosolol a demak, caay ka i Yin-co- min-co ato Tangafolan a finacahan, o Cen- fo ko pi'arawan. Mafana'ay kako deng o pita'ong caayay katatodong, kianini litapang mihalaka ko Cen-fo to midemakan no Yin- co-min-co, itini tona demak a mahapinang so'linay misololay konini a Kitaki.
english: Today is only a beginning. The duty for reconciliation lies not with the indigenous peoples and the Pingpu ethnic group, but with the government. I know that words of apology alone are not enough. What we actually do for the indigenous peoples will decide whether reconciliation succeeds or stumbles.

ami: So'linen ako a palosiyang, o papatirengen i Cong-tong-fo ko "yofayof no mocelay a saway no Yin-co-min-co ato mifalic palamo^celay a iing-kay". Kako o Cong-tong ko kakeridan nonini a sa'opo^, malakapot to dayhiw no kalofinacadan mikilim to mocelay a saway, ikor i, malecaday ko paenaran a malacafay mihalaka to demak no Kitakit.
english: Therefore, I am here to announce that we are setting up an Indigenous Historical Justice and Transitional Justice Commission under the Presidential Office. As the head of state, I will serve as convener and work hand in hand with tribal representatives to pursue historical justice. We will also discuss, on the basis of equality, the future policy direction of this country.

ami: So'linen no mako a pasowal, o iingkay i Cong-tong-fo i, malecaday ko paenaran ato nika tadamaan. O saka ira no dayhiw no kalofinacadan ato Tangafolan i, o nikalecad no faloco' no niyaro' ko tapang. Onini a yofayof i, o mihalakaay to kalodemak no Yin- co-min-co, orasaka, manga'ay a talafafawen ko ngiha' no finawlan.
english: I want to stress that this commission places the greatest importance on equality between the country and the indigenous peoples. The election of tribal representatives, including for the Pingpu ethnic group, will take as basis the consensus of peoples and tribes. This commission will serve as a mechanism for collective decision-making by indigenous peoples, and will ensure that the voices of tribe members find true expression.

ami: O roma sato, longocen ako ko Sin-cen-yin patosok to romi'ad a mikayki to saki "milahciay to paranaan a rikec no Yin-co-min-co a iingkay". O mihalakaan no iingkay i, manga'ay a malalicay to Cen-fo, ato i kalosa'opo^ no Sin-cen-yin, a misalof to demak. Mato mikilim to masafaloco'ay a saway, palowad to pakoniyaniyah pikowan, saka comahadnosaka'orip,pirayraytoserangawanato sapasifana', saka ci pa'es no tireng, ato pidipot to i tokayay ko 'orip a finacadan.
english: In addition, I will request that our Executive Yuan convene regularly the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law Promotion Committee, and use the Yuan's authority to coordinate and handle matters related to any consensus reached by the above-mentioned commission. These matters include the following: to retrieve historical memories, to promote indigenous self-government, to seek fair economic development, to ensure continuation of culture and education, to safeguard indigenous health, and to protect the rights of urban indigenous peoples, etc.

ami: Oya aniniay a rikec ato serangawan no Yin- co-min-co, iraay ko masasiikoray, orasaka, patirengen ita ko mafana'ay to no rikec a " saki rikec a tayal to Yin-co-min-co a sa'opo^" sanay, ta masaysay malowan ko rawraw i nanaman no 'orip no Yin-co-min-co ato sakedec a rikec no Kitakit.
english: Where modern laws and indigenous traditional cultures are at odds, we will set up an Indigenous Legal Service Center with a high degree of cultural sensitivity, to reduce through institutional design the growing clashes between indigenous customs and modern laws.

ami: Wa ira ko pilongoc no mako to kaloyofayof a sa'opo^, misakalamkam a misalof to mapatalahoingay ciraraway na mi'adop i saliyoh, yo cilekakawa ko Yin-co-min-co, nawahani, citama' i caay ko sapili'acaaw. Orasaka, kilimen no mita ko saka nga'ay a makaykic nonini a demak.
english: I will ask the relevant agencies to immediately pull together cases in which indigenous community members have been indicted or sentenced for hunting, where the hunting was done in accordance with traditional customs, on traditional lands, and for non-transactional needs, and where the animals hunted were not protected by conservation laws. For such cases we will deliberate solutions.

ami: Longocen haca ako ko kaloyofayof a sa'opo^, pasadak to masamaanay ko demak sa mapateli i Fotod ko cisawarakay a 'afo no he-neng sanay a codad. Ta i'ayaw no nika losimet nonini a 'afo no he-neng i, pafelien ko Fotod a finacadan to matatodongay a sapalolol.
english: I will also direct relevant agencies to present an investigative report on the decision-making process of nuclear waste storage on Orchid Island. Before finding a permanent solution for the nuclear waste, we will provide the Yami tribe appropriate compensation.

ami: I kangodo^ to Tangafolan ao Tangafolan kami sanay to 'orip no niyah i, 'ayaw no 9 a folad saka 30 a romi'ad i, maainiini kami to pakayniay i rikec, ta maanen a pafeli ko Tangafolan a finacadan to malonangraan a tatodong.
english: At the same time, under the principle of respecting the Pingpu ethnic group's self- identity, and recognizing their identity, we will examine relevant laws before September 30 of this year, so that Pingpu ethnic group identity will receive the rights and status it deserves.

ami: Anini a mihcaan 11 ko folad saka 1 a romi'ad, litapangto kami a nikenis pahapinang to saliyoh a sera no Yin-co- min-co. O citodongay to rikec no niyaro' i, litapangayto a matayal, saka, a hacecay han a nilahci ko niharatengan to pakoniyaniyah pikowan. Paroharohen no niyam a pasadak i Li-fa-Yin ko tadamaanay a demak no Yin-co-min-co to "rikec no pakoniyaniyah pikowan", "rikec no sera ato riyar", "rikec no saka comahad no sowal".
english: On November 1 of this year, we will begin to delineate and announce indigenous traditional territories and lands. The system of tribal public corporation is already in place. In the future, the ideals of indigenous self-government will be realized step by step. We will step up the pace and submit for legislative deliberation three laws of great importance to indigenous peoples: the Indigenous Peoples Self-Government Law, the Indigenous Peoples Land and Sea Areas Law, and the Indigenous Languages Development Law.

ami: Anini herek no lahok, pasa'opo^en niyam ko polong no Yin-co-min-co sin-cen a pikayki. Paratoh ko Cen-fo to adihayay a mihalakaan a demak. To mihcacaan no 8 a folad saka 1 a romi'ad, o paparatoh ko Sin-cen-yin i polong no Yin-co-min-co to nidemakan a mo^celay a saway ato fa^lohay a palamocelan a demak. Lahcien ko tapang a rikec no Yin-co-min-co, lahcien ko mo^celay a saway, ta mapatereng ko paranaan no pakoniyaniyah pikowan, onini a tolo^ay ko hahalakaen no Cen-fo to demak no Yin-co-min-co.
english: Later this afternoon, we will convene a national indigenous peoples administrative meeting. In that meeting, the government will elaborate on the policies. On every August 1 to come, the Executive Yuan will report to the indigenous peoples our progress on restoring historical justice and transitional justice. To implement the Indigenous Peoples Basic Law, to serve indigenous historical justice, and to lay the foundation for indigenous self- government – these are the three major goals for the government's policy towards indigenous peoples.

ami: Longocen ako ko iniay, minengnengay to tilifi ato mitiya polong no Yin-co-min-co, malacafay kita a pawacay mikantok tonini a demak. Nanay sa'icelen namo o Yin-co-min-co a mitiwatiw, paini to fana', ta malahci ko nihaydaan no Cen- fo, so'lin mifalic ko moraraway a demak i'ayaw.
english: To all of our indigenous friends here and watching on TV and online: I invite you to stand witness. I invite you not to endorse, but to oversee. Please keep pressure on the government and right its course where necessary, so that it will realize its commitments and right historical wrongs.

ami: Aray han ako ko polong no Yin-co-min-co, kamo ko mipalalay to polong no Kitakit, onini a nipasaripa'an a sera^ ato rayray no to'as, iraay ko caay ko mamafalic a satadamaanay, onini a satadamaanay i, o papafelien to sakangod ciira.
english: I want to thank all of our indigenous friends. You remind everyone in this country that there is irreplaceable value in the land we tread on and the traditions we inherit. This value deserves dignity.

ami: Iikor to i, pakaynien niyam i pilahci to mihalakaan a tayal, to saka caay ka lasawad kapawan to sowal ato serangawan ko teloc no Yin-co-min-co, ato maro'ay tonini a pala^ no Taywan a finacadan, ta caayto ka matiya o pakoyocay a misatiwatiwal i pala^ no niyah.
english: In the future, we will push for policies to ensure that succeeding generations of indigenous tribes and all ethnic peoples in Taiwan never lose their languages and memories, that they are never separated from their cultural traditions, and that never again are they lost in a land of their own.

ami: Longocen ako ko polong no Siya-kay malacafay a misa'icel, mafana' to saway, to pala^, to kasasiroma no serangawan no mita. Pasayraen i kasasiri'ay, malacafay , sasipalada' ko rakat no mita i Taywan, ta so'linay fa^lohay a kitakit koni.
english: I call upon our entire society to come together and get to know our history, get to know our land, and get to know the cultures of our many ethnic peoples. Let us work towards reconciliation, a shared existence and shared prosperity, and a new future for Taiwan.

ami: Longocen no mako ko polong no finawlan, pakayni tona demak anini, malacafay kita a palowad to mo^celay masolinga'ay a kitakit, o cecay a so'linay malalenay a kitakit.
english: I call upon all citizens to seize the opportunities offered by this day – to join together, work hard, and build a country of justice, a country of true diversity and equality.

ami: U maan ko sinavel no mita
english: a malahuk saw?" "Aw maan u kavitu i"

ami: Inito haw kita, ta! Malingato to kita.
Kapah haw kamo alomanay! I nipicodad no mita anini a remiad, a pasevana' kako i tamowan to ngangan no kakaenan no Pangcah.
english: Hello everyone. Today, I am going to teach you how to say the Ami language for food.

ami: Mavana' to haw kiso a mitengil to sowal no pasevana'ay?
english: Do you understand what the teacher says?

ami: Caay kava:na' kako a mitengil to sowal no miso pasevana'ay, kapah to haw a kinacacay aca a miliyaw a semowal?
english: I don’t understand. Can you repeat it again?

ami: Caay pakatengil kako, kapa:h to haw a satataangen ato:di?
english: I can’t hear you, can you speak louder?

ami: Pimelawi itini! Dodoen ko nipiasip no mako.
english: Look here, please! Repeat after me.

ami: Hay! Kapah ko niasip no miso.
Kakinacacay aca a miasip, satataangen atodi.
english: Read it again. Please speak louder.

ami: Pasevana'ay! Mapawan kako a mikerid to sapisorit no mako.
english: I forgot to bring my pen.

ami: Pasevana'ay, mapawan kako a mikerid to savoric.
english: I forgot to bring my eraser.

ami: Picaliwi to savoric no teparay no miso.
english: Please borrow erasers from your classmates.

ami: Pacaliwi kako to savoric no miso.
Maherek to ko nipicodad no mita.
Tangasa itini ko nipinanam no mita, romaaw to a lipayan a malalitemoh.
english: Class dismissed, see you next week.

ami: U wawa ni Marang kako, ci Tomay ko ngangan no mako.
english: I’m Marang’s son, my name is Tumay.

ami: U micodaday ni Looh kako, ci Tomay ko ngangan no mako,
english: I am a student of Luuh, my name is Tumay.

ami: Maan han saw ko ngangan no miso?
Ci Tomay han ko ngangan no mako.
Cima han saw ko ngangan ni ama iso.
Ci Marang han ko ngangan ni ama ako.
U vavainayan a kaka no mako cira, ci Kilang han ko ngangan nira.
english: He’s my brother, his name is Kilang.

ami: Cima han saw ko ngangan nira?
Ci Kilang han ko ngangan nira.
Ci Valiyos han haw ko ngangan nira?
Hay! Ci Valiyos han ko ngangan nira.
Ci Valiyos haw ko ngangan nira?
Caay, ci Kilang ko ngangan nira.
Ci Panay cira, o vayi no mako cira.
U cavay no mako cira, Ci Nakaw han ko ngangan nira.
english: She’s my friend, her name is Nakaw.

ami: Pina to saw ko mihcaan no miso?
Moketep to ko mihcaan no mako.
Pina to saw ko mihcaan nira?
Savaw to tosa ko mihcaan nira.
Pina to saw ko mihcaan ni ama no miso?
Lima a polo' to ko mihcaan ni ama ako.

english: How many brothers and sisters do you have?

ami: Cacay ko kaka to vavainayan, cacay ko kaka to vavahian, cacay ko sava to vavainayan no mako.
english: I have a brother, a sister and a younger brother.

ami: Awaay ko vavainayan a kaka no mako.
Papina saw ko tamdaw no loma' namo?
english: How many people are in your family?

ami: Sasepat ko tamdaw no loma' niyam.
english: There are four of us in our family.

ami: U maan saw ko dademaken ni vaki no miso?
english: What does your uncle do for a living?

ami: U vavahian a kaka no mako cira.

english: Does your sister have a job?
Are these two people brothers and sisters?

ami: U Pangcah haw ko vavahi no miso?
Tarakaw haw ci ama no miso?
Hayi! Tarakaw amin ko loma' niyam.
english: Yes, we are all very tall.

ami: Micodad to haw ko vavahian a sava no miso?
english: Does your sister go to school?

ami: Mavana' haw ko sava no miso a misanoPangcah?
english: Do your siblings speak the language?

ami: Hayi! Mavana' ko heni a misanoPangcah.
english: Yes, they speak the ethnic language.
How many brothers and sisters do you have?
I have three brothers and sisters.

ami: Makomod haw ko aro' no miso ato ina aci ama?
english: Do you live with your parents?

ami: Makomod haw ko aro' no miso ato vaki aci vayi?
english: Do you live with your grandparents?

ami: Caay, caay kakomod ko aro' no mako ato heni.
english: No, I didn't live with them.

ami: Cima saw ko mikomoday i tisowan?
Makomod ko aro' no mako ato ina, ama, kaka to vavainayan.
english: I live with my father, mother and brother.

ami: Icowa saw ko niyaro' no miso?
I Hoalien ko niyaro' no mako.
A hacowa saw kiso a taloma' i niyaro'?
english: When are you going back to the tribe?

ami: I pipantangan no lalodan taloma' to kako.
english: I will go back in the summer.
The sun is coming out, it's very hot.
Is it going to be cold outside?
It's cold, so wear more clothes.

ami: Masitodong ko remiad anini, sademsem saan.
english: It's neither cold nor hot today, very comfortable.

ami: Mamaan saw ko remiad nina lavii?
Awaay ko kotem, masadak to ko vois.
english: There were no clouds in the sky; the stars came out.

ami: Salaw sahen ko orad, masadak to ko cidal, tahekal to ko talakal ni Adek.
english: The rain has just stopped, the sun has come out, the rainbow is coming out.

ami: Mamaan saw ko remiad i tamowan?

english: We're going to have a big storm here.

ami: Kapah haw ko remiad i tamowan?

english: Very well, out of the big sun.

ami: A tara to kako a micodad.
english: I have to go to school.

ami: Sienaw ko remiad, saadihayen to ko nikasivodoy.
english: The weather is very cold, so wear more clothes.

ami: A tataang ko orad anosani, keriden to ko cacevaren.
english: It's going to rain heavily, you have to remember to bring an umbrella.

ami: Navetili'an nasani, a oradan to anosani.
english: There was thunder just now, and it's supposed to rain later.
It just rained, and now it's stopped.

ami: Mahaen naoradan, mararemed ko lalan kiyami.
english: It seems to have rained and the road is wet.

ami: Naoradan haw? Kiya matopic saw ko tiretirengan no miso.
english: Is it raining? Why are you all wet?

ami: Uradan i hekal, nacaay kasicacevaren kako.
english: It's raining outside, so I didn't bring an umbrella.

ami: Tanovali saan, adada toaca ko tangal no mako.
english: The wind is blowing so hard that my head hurts.

ami: Tataak ko cidal, adada toaca ko tangal no mako a mapa'ing'ing.
english: The sun is so big, it makes me dizzy.
I forgot to bring my pen.
I forgot to bring my chopsticks.
Me too, let's go buy it.
Let's go! Let's go buy a pen, shall we?

ami: Hayi!, a micakay aca kako to savoric.
english: Well, I still have to buy erasers.
Let's go get breakfast, shall we?
No, I've already eaten at home.

ami: Mapawan kako a pa'ecoy to tavo no mako.
english: I forgot to steam my lunchbox.
I forgot to bring my lunchbox.

ami: Tatoekaw to no mita a kemaen to tavo no mako.
english: Then let's eat my lunch box together!

ami: A o maan saw ko sakalahok no miso?
english: What are you having for lunch?

ami: A o niparasor no cacodadan a tavo ko sakalahok no mako.
english: I want to eat the lunch prepared by the school.

ami: A o maan saw ko sakalahok no miso?
english: What are you having for lunch?

ami: Sitavo kako anini a remiad, matatoeka kita a malahok.
english: I've brought a lunchbox today, let's eat together at noon!
Let's go play basketball, shall we?
Let's go! Let's go play baseball.
No, I have books to read.

ami: Padangi aca kako a miala to saasik.
english: Please help me with the broom.

ami: Padangi aca kako a miala to sasisit.
english: Can you get me a rag, please?
I'm sweeping the floor, you ask Tumay to help you.

ami: Maherek to haw kiso a miasik?

english: The floor is dirty, go clean it.

ami: Hay, alaay to no mako ko sasipo.
english: Okay, I'll go get the cloth.

ami: Tanooning saan kira sasingarang, sipoen aca.
english: That window is very dirty, go clean it.

ami: Akahenay, caay henay kaherek ko nipiasik no mako.
english: Wait a minute, I'm not done sweeping here yet.

ami: A o maan saw ko demaken no miso anosani?

english: I'm going to see my teacher.

ami: A mimaan saw kiso i naherekan no nipicodad?
english: What do you do after school?
I'm going to sing with my friends.

ami: A mimaan saw cira i naherekan no nipicodad?
I loma' to haw ci Lisin?
english: May I ask if Lisin is home?
She’s at home, please come in.

ami: I loma' to haw ci Lisin?
english: May I ask if Lisin is home?

ami: Awaay cira, a mimaan saw kiso?
english: She's not here, what can I do for you?

ami: Vaki! Ci Panay kako, vohaten aca ko panan.
english: Grandpa, I'm Panay, please open the door.

ami: Kacaw, ci Kilang kako, tayni a miholol isaw.
english: Kacaw, I'm Kilang, I'm here to play.

ami: Matenes to a caay kasasoaraw kiyami.
Halis! Maoron to i tisowan hani, Kati, picomodi.
english: Yeah! I miss you so much. Come on, let's chat!
Please sit down and have some tea.
Come on! Please have some tea.

ami: Ayi! aleso' saan a nanomen kina ocia.
Hayi, saaleso' saan a melawen kina ciyak.
Maherek to ci ina a misakalavi, kati! Kemana to kita.
english: Mom has cooked dinner, let's eat!
Okay, I'll go wash my hands.

ami: Dopoh han a kemaen, o tao hanay maan kiso.
english: Try to eat and drink as much as possible, you're not an outsider.

ami: Adihay to ko nikaen no mako, mave:col to kako.
english: I ate a lot, I'm full.

ami: Pitongali a kemaen, o maan saw ko kangodoan.
A taloma' to kako, romaaw to a tayni a miliso' i tisowan.
english: I'm going home, I'll see you next time.

ami: Hayi, naon hanto isaw ko rakat.
I lavii to! a taloma' to kako.

english: Then take care and go slowly!

ami: Hayi, ano silawad tayni hanto i loma' no mako a miholol.
english: Okay, come to my house sometime.

ami: Inito haw kita! A hakolongen no mako kamo anini a remiad, tayra kita a miliso' to matoasay no niyaro'.
english: Hello everyone, today I’m taking you to the tribe to interview the elders.

ami: Vakiaw! Tayni kami a miliso' i tisowan.
english: Grandpa, we’ve come to see you.

ami: Iho! Mavana' haw kamo a misanoPangcah? Piolah' waro!
Kapah haw kamo! A hakolongen no mako kamo a tayra i nipalomaan to havay a mawmah.
english: Hello everyone, today I will take you to work in the millet field.

ami: Katayni itini a masasilsil, aka kapawan a mikerid to sakawmah.
english: Come and line up, remember to bring your tools.

ami: Hay pasevana'ay, irato ko nirapetan niyam to sakamaomah.
english: Yes, sir, we’ve got our tools.

ami: Caay hen, maraay henay ko rarakatan.
english: Not yet, it’s still far away.
You go and pick up the grass.

ami: Hay! Akoay ko mirisrisay to rengos.
Pialai kiso to sapivahoy to ayam.
english: You go get the bird catcher.

ami: Hayi, akoay ko mivahoyay to ayam.
english: Okay, I’ll go and catch the birds.

ami: Kapah to haw kita, a tayra kita anini a remiad i mamelawen to nirovoan a aadopen.
english: Hello everyone, we are going to the zoo today.

ami: Solinay haw? A makamaan saw kita a tayra?
english: Really? How are we going to get there?

ami: Sakapahen ko nipisilsil, a micakay to kita to paya.
english: Everyone line up, we are ready to buy tickets.

ami: U ayam ko aayaway, o oner ko lalikolay, kaamo hanto ko mimelaway.
english: There are birds in the front and snakes in the back.

ami: Asiroma, ka o ayam aca ko melawen no miso.
english: It doesn’t matter, then you go and watch the birds.

ami: Herek no cacay a tatokian, itini kita a malecapo.
english: We’ll be back in an hour.

ami: Na o maan saw ko nikamelawen no miso?
Adihay ko nikamelawan no mako to oner, adihay aca ko ayam.
english: I saw a lot of snakes and a lot of birds.
Hurry up, we have to go.

ami: Akahenay saw! Matimel ko koko' no mako.
english: Wait for me, my feet are tired.
There are a lot of people swimming here.

ami: Talolong ko itilaay a nanom, itini hanaw to no mita a midangoy.
english: The water there is deep, so we just swim here.

ami: Na o maan saw ko dadakawen no miso a taini?
english: What kind of car did you take?

ami: Maanen saw no miso a tala cacodadan?
english: How do you get to school?

ami: Makamaan saw cira a tayra i cacodadan to kaloremiad?
english: How does he usually go to school?

ami: Maka cie-yon a tayra i cacodadan cira.
english: He took the subway to school.

ami: Makamaan saw ci vayi no miso a micakay to dateng?
english: How does your grandmother go to the grocery store?

ami: Makaotovay cira a micakay to dateng.
english: She went to the grocery store on a motorcycle.

ami: A maanen saw no miso a tara i Botod?
english: How are you going to get to Orchid Island?

ami: A makalonan kako a tara i Botod.
english: I want to take a boat to Lanyu.

ami: A makamaan saw cira a tara i Botod?
english: How did he get to Orchid Island?

ami: A makahikoki cira a tara i Botod.
english: He took a plane to Orchid Island.

ami: A makamaan saw cira a tara i Kaosong?.
english: What bus did he take to Kaohsiung?

ami: A maka kao-tie cira a tara i Kaosong.
english: He took the THSR to Kaohsiung.

ami: Na o silamalay haw ko dakawen nira a tara i Posong?
english: Did he take a train to Taitung?

ami: Hayi! Na o silamalay ko dakawen nira a tara i Posong.
english: Yes, he took a train to Taitung.

ami: Na o silamalay haw ko dakawen nira a tara i Posong?
english: Did he take a train to Taitung?

ami: Caay isaw, na o hikoki ko dakawen nira a tara i Posong.
english: No, he took a plane to Taitung.

ami: Sipangirowan haw no vaso i ngata?
english: Is there a bus stop near here?

ami: Hay, ira to! vesoc han kina lalan, a mamelaw to no miso ko pangirowan no vaso.
english: Yes, if you go straight ahead, you will see the bus stop.

ami: Icowa saw ko sakangataay a cie-yon-can itini?
english: Where is the nearest MRT station?

ami: Awaay ko cie-yon-can itini, a o takosi a cacay ko dadakawen no miso.
english: There is no MRT station here, you can only take a taxi.

ami: Ano makavaso kako, a hacowa saw ko tenes a tangasa i cacodadan?
english: How long does it take to get to the school by bus?

ami: Cacay a polo' ira ko lima a sasoritan tangasato.
Ano maka kaw-tie, a hacowa saw ko tenes a tangasa i Taychong?
english: How long does it take to get to Taichung by THSR?

ami: Cacay a tatokiyan tangasa to i Taychong.
english: I will come to Taichung in an hour.

ami: A hacowa saw ko tenes ano makacidosiya a tara i Ulay?
english: Is it a long drive to Ulai?

ami: A hacowa saw ko tenes ano maka cie-yon kiso a tayni i loma' no mako?
english: How long did it take you to come to my house by subway?

ami: Tosa a polo' a sasoritan tangasato.
english: It takes 20 minutes to get there.
Do you know how to ride a bicycle?
Yes! I can ride a bicycle.

ami: Mangaay hakiya ano tara kako a miliso' i tisowan?
Mangaay hakiya ano tara kako a miliso' i tisowan?
A caay kako, caay kaadihay ko nikavana'an no mako isaw.
english: Don’t, I don’t know much about it.

ami: Mangalay isaw kako a miliso' i tisowan, silawad hakiya kiso i herek no kalahokan?
english: Are you free this afternoon? I’d like to visit you, is that okay?

ami: Hayi! Talaay to no mako kiso i loma'.
english: Okay, I’ll wait for you at home.

ami: Silawad haw kiso anocila? Ira isaw ko papalitaan no mako to rayray no Pangcah.
english: Are you free tomorrow? I would like to ask you about the legends of the Amis.

ami: A talalotok kako anocila, a awaay i loma' isaw.
english: I’m going to the mountains tomorrow, so I won’t be home.

ami: Matesek ko nikavana'an no miso to lekakawa no Pangcah saan ko nikatengil no mako. Sisa, mangalay isaw kako a mipalita i tisowan.
english: I heard that you know a lot about Amis traditions and customs, so I would like to ask you a few questions.

ami: Caay kahacowa ko nikavana' no mako, nika, sadakadakay hanaw to no mako a pacaov.
english: I don’t know much about it, but I will try to answer as best I can.

ami: Kapah to haw a lo-inen no mako? Hangay maangaay a dodoen a misorit i nalikolan.
english: Can I record the video? It will be easier to record in the future.

ami: Pinato saw ko mihcaan no miso anini?
Siwato a polo' ira ko walo ko mihcaan no mako.
I terongay hen a miheca a melawen ko tireng iso haw.

english: What tribe do you come from?

ami: U Pangcah to haw ko vavahi no miso?
U macowaay saw a sasowalen ko kavana'an no miso?
Mavana' kako a semowal to no Pangcah ato no Poyoma isaw.
english: I can speak Ami and Puyuma.

ami: Maolah kako anini a remiad a miliso' i tisowan, kedamay kasemowal may to paysin i nipiadopan namo?
english: It’s a pleasure to interview you today, can you talk about the taboos you have when it comes to hunting?

ami: Hayi, kapah to! Yo masakapah hen hinatayra kami i lotok a miadop.
english: Yes. We used to go hunting in the mountains when we were young.

ami: Tadamaan ko nipasevana' no miso itina remiadan, aray han no mako kiso.
english: Thank you, what you taught me today was really great.

ami: No namaka toasay solinayay amin ko nipakongkoan no mako.
english: All that I say is true, the sayings of my ancestors.

ami: Hatilaaw to ko nikasasowal no mita, awaay to ko sasowalen to nipavatis no miso, aray han no mako kiso.
english: This is the end of our interview today. Thank you very much for sharing with us.

ami: Aka haeni ko sowal, romaaw to kita a masasowal.
english: Don’t say that, let’s talk about it next time.

ami: Hatilaaw to ko demak ita, halhalay to saadihayaw to ko nipakongko anoroma.
english: That’s all we’ve done. We look forward to hearing more stories next time.

ami: Hayi to! naon han to ko rakat.
Ini haw kiso, o maan saw ko cakayen no miso?
english: Hello, what do you want to buy?
I want to buy a cup.

ami: Ini haw kiso, o maan saw ko cakayen no miso?
english: Hello, what do you want to buy?

ami: Mangalay kako a micakay to toper.
english: I want to buy a hat.

ami: A micakay kako to kopo, pacakay haw kamo?
english: I want to buy a cup, do you sell them?

ami: Ira to! a pina saw ko cacakayan no miso?
english: Yes, how many do you want to buy?

ami: Awaay! Caay pacakay kami to icep.
english: No, we don't sell betel nut.

ami: Mangalay kako a micakay to velac.
A pina saw a tavo ko nipicakay no miso?
english: How many packs do you want to buy?

ami: Toloen a tavo ko nipaveli i takowan.

english: I want to buy sweet potatoes.

ami: Awaayto! maeminto a pacakayen ko vonga.
english: No more! All the potatoes are sold out.

ami: A micakay kako to simal, tosa a sinatowik.
english: I want to buy two bottles of oil.

ami: Ca:cay to a sinatowikan ko osaw.
english: We only have one bottle left.

ami: Patadoi hen isaw kako a micakay to litaol.
english: Go buy an egg for me.

ami: A pina saw a dadoy ko nipicakay no miso?
english: How many pounds do you want to buy?

ami: A pina saw a dadoy ko nipicakay no miso to litaol?
english: How many pounds of eggs do you want to buy?

ami: A tosa a dadoy ko nipicakay no mako.
english: I want to buy two catties.

ami: A micakay kako to kenaw, tosaen a kamel.
english: I want to buy two green onions.

ami: Tolo to a kamel ko osaw, hamisoen to amin.
english: There are three left, all for you!

ami: Pina saw ko aca nina velac?
english: How much is this bag of rice?

ami: Cacay a tavo tosa a patekenan ko aca
Komod han tosa a polo' ira ko cacay, tosa a polo' hanaw to ko nipisaosi.

english: That's very kind of you, thank you!

ami: Siwa a polo' ira ko lima kinian.
Tongalay no mako ko nipicakay, edemaw ko cacay a patekenan.
english: I'll buy some more, so I can make up $100.

ami: Komod han ko aca, lima a patekenan ira ko moketep.
Masa saw? ano limaen a patekenan ko nipaaca no mako?
Matekes isaw, masasaw a kelolen atodi ko aca?
english: It's too expensive, can you reduce it a bit?

ami: A caay isaw, awaay to ko kakelolen.
english: No, this can't be reduced any further.

ami: Inian a piyangan ko alaan no mako.
english: I'll take this packet of cookies.

ami: Tolo a polo' ko aca nina piyang, ira hen haw ko kangalayan?
english: $30 for the cookies, anything else you need?

ami: Madengay to haw kiso a pacaliw to pida i takowan.
english: Can I borrow money from you?

ami: Hay isaw! A hacowa saw ko nipicaliw no miso?
english: Yes! How much do you need?

ami: Mapawan kako to papidaan hani, caliway aca ko pida no miso?
english: I forgot to bring my money, can you lend me your money?

ami: Mahaen kako, awaay ko nipikerid no mako to pida.
english: I don't have any money either!

ami: Mapawan kako to papidaan hani, caliway aca ko pida no miso?
english: I forgot to bring my wallet, can I borrow money from you?

ami: Aka, caay hen kiso panokas to nicaliwan i naayaw.
english: No, you haven't paid me back the money you borrowed last time.

ami: Hayi, keda! Kaiso to ko mialaay.
Pacaliwen aca kako to codad no miso.
Pacaliwi kako to vatikar no miso?
Hayi! Nika, a panokasen to no miso anocila.
english: Okay, but you have to return it tomorrow.

ami: Uradan to! caay kasicacevaren kako, caliway hen aca ko cacevaren no miso.
english: It's raining, I don't have an umbrella, can you lend me your umbrella?

ami: Ca:cay ko cacevaren no mako, cacayat hanaw to no mita.
english: I only have an umbrella, let's stick together!

ami: U nipacaliwan no miso kina codad i takowan inacila, ya! panokasay to no mako kiso.
english: Here's the book you lent me last time, take it and give it back.

ami: Ano ira hen ko mamamelawen a codad, sowal hanto kako.
english: You can tell me what else you want to read.

ami: A hacowa saw kako a panokas i tisowan to nicaliwan a pida?
english: When do I have to pay you back?

ami: Asiroma, ano sipida kiso itiya han to a panokas.
english: It's okay, you can talk about it when you have money.

ami: A hacowa saw kiso a panokas to nicaliwan a pida i takowan?
english: When are you going to pay me back?

ami: Cilaaw to no mako a panokas i tisowan.
english: I will return it to you tomorrow.

ami: A hacowa to saw kiso a panokas to nicaliwan a codad i takowan?
english: When are you (exactly) going to return my book?

ami: Napanokasento no mako kiso inacila kiyami.
english: Didn't I return it to you yesterday?

ami: Nipacaliwan haw ni Kacaw kina sapisorit i tisowan?
english: Did Kacaw lend you this pen?

ami: Hayi! Nicaliwan no mako i ciraan anini a remiadan.
english: Yes, I borrowed it from him today.

ami: Nicaliwan haw no miso ci Kacawan kina sapisorit?
english: Did you borrow this pen from Kacaw?

ami: Caay, o nicakayan ni ina ako.
english: No, this is what mom bought.

ami: Awaayto ko cilah, caliwen ko cilah na Panay.
english: We're out of salt, go borrow some from Panay.

ami: Papinokasen ci Panay to nicaliwan nira a pida i takowan.
english: Go tell Panay to pay me back.

ami: Pina saw ko nitadahan nira to pida i tisowan?
english: How much does she owe you?

ami: A tayra padatengan kako a paloma to dateng.
english: I’m going to plant vegetables in the garden.

ami: Tanorengos saan, mivirsiw kako to rengos, a pananom aca anosani.
english: There’s too much grass, I’m cutting the grass, I have to water it later.

ami: Padangen aca kako a miala to kakawit ato tatak?
english: Will you get my scythes and hoes, please?

ami: Icowaen saw no miso a pateli?
I tapiingan no tavi ko nipateli.
english: Put it next to the plow rake.
Did you turn over the soil?

ami: Maheka nitavien no mako, a paloma to anosani.
english: I just turned over the soil, and so on to sow seeds.

ami: Dengay to haw a datengen ko nipalomaan no miso?
english: Are your vegetables ready to be harvested?

ami: Dengay to a datengen ko itiniay a tamana, iraayay a maoway a caay hen ka o dadatengan.
english: The cabbage here is ready to be harvested, but the Showa grass there is not yet ready to be harvested.

ami: Hovaw! Kiya hatila to saw ko nivongaan no miso?
english: Wow! You dug up so many gourds.
Can you store the sweet potatoes in the barn?
We were throwing nets to catch fish.

ami: Adihayto ko nitavokodan niyam i vovo.
english: We’ve been catching a lot of fish in the fish traps.

ami: Maanen saw namo a mivoting i kaloremiadan?
english: How do you usually catch fish?
I use a gossip net to catch fish.

ami: Pana'en haw no miso ko nipiadop?
english: Do you know how to hunt with a bow and arrow?

ami: U veteric a tekeran ko sapiadop no mako, yo roma sikowang pasowaco a miadop.
english: I usually catch my prey with a trap, but occasionally I hunt with a gun and a dog.

ami: U rarakatan no vavoy no lotok kina lalan.
english: This is the road the boar took.

ami: No vavoy a narakatan kinian, manay, o rarakatan no vavoy no lotok kina lalan isaw.
english: These are the footprints of the boar, so this is the path the boar took.

ami: Kalamkamaw no mita a milido' to nipatekeran, mahaen simalepelay no tama'.
english: Go and see our trap, for it seems that we have caught our prey.

ami: Mahiphip to no waco ko silet no vavoy, sakalamkamaw no mita a mikoko.
english: The dog seems to have smelled it. Let’s go after them.

ami: U maan saw ko sanga'en no miso?
Misaerid kako to sapiteker to tolok.
english: I’m making lasso traps to catch pheasants.

ami: U maan saw kira nipateliyan no miso itila?.
english: What is that thing you put there?

ami: U sasekerot a teker kiraan, o sapilepel to mancel.
english: It was a leg-rigged rope trap, and we used it to catch Shankiang.

ami: Mapalemed kita no kawas, adihay ko tama' no mita i anini a remiad.
english: Thanks to the blessing of our ancestors, we had a great harvest today.

ami: Hayi o! ano tangasa to i loma' iri, pavavatis hanaw to ko cavacavay.
english: Yes! Let’s share it with our friends and family when we get home!

ami: Anini a remiad a pasevana' kako i tamowan, a maan han a semowal ko mananowangay a ma'oripay to sowal no Pangcah.
english: I will teach everyone all kinds of animals in Pangcah language today.

ami: Anini a remiad a pasevana' kako i tamowan, a maan han a semowal ko lemangaway to sowal no Pangcah.
english: I will teach everyone all kinds of plants in Pangcah language today.

ami: Anini a remiad a pasevana' kako i tamowan, a maan han a semowal ko nipalomaan a heci to sowal no Pangcah.
english: I will teach everyone all kinds of fruits in Pangcah language today.

ami: U ni Kacaw haw kira vodoy?
Caay, o ni Panay a pakitopen kinian.
Pasevana'ay, mapawan kako a mikerid to codad no mako.
english: Teacher, I didn’t bring my textbook.

ami: Kahekolong ato i teparay a mimelaw to codad.
english: Share the book with your classmate next to you.

ami: Pacaliway no mako kiso to savoric no mako.
english: I will lend you my eraser.

ami: A pahanhan to kita namicodad, piarawi to rakat a taloma'!
english: It is the end of the class, be careful on your way home.

ami: A pahanhan to kita namicodad, olihaw kamo!
english: The class is over, goodbye everyone.

ami: Inito haw kita, ci Using ko ngagan no mako.
english: Hello everyone, my name is Using.

ami: Inito haw kita, ci Komod ko ngangan no mako.
english: Hello everyone, my name is Kumud.

ami: Kapah haw kiso, ci Potal kako.
Kapah haw kiso Potal, ci Voting kako.
Kapah haw kiso, ci Adop kako.
Kapah haw kiso, ci Lais kako.
Ci ina ni Valah kako, ci Lisin kako.
U sava ni Valah kako, ci Vahi ko ngangan no mako.
english: I am Balah’s sister. My name is Vahi.

ami: U pasevana'ay no mako cira, ci Valiyos ko ngangan nira.
U kaka no mako cira, ci Kilang ko ngangan nira.
U cavay no mako ci Lais.
Cima saw ko ngangan no kaka no miso?
english: What is your elder sister’s name?

ami: Ci Aniw ko ngangan ni kaka ako.
english: My elder sister’s name is Aniw.

ami: Cima saw ko ngangan no sava no miso?
english: What is your younger sister’s name?

ami: Ci Tipos ko ngangan no sava ako.
english: My younger sister’s name is Tipus.

ami: Mavana' haw kiso to ngangan nira?
Pinaay to saw ko mihecaan no kaka no miso?
english: How old is your elder brother?

ami: Savaw to lima ko mihecaan nira.
Pina to saw ko mihecaan no sava no miso?
english: How old is your younger brother?
Do you have schools in your community?

ami: I niyaro'ay haw a cacodadan a micodad kiso?
english: Do you study in your tribe’s school?

ami: Hay, matiyato o laloma'an kami a micodad i cacodadan.
english: Yes, we are like family while we are studying at school.

ami: U kaka to vavahian no mako cira.
U sava to vavainayan no mako cira.
U mamaanay saw a demak ko demaken ni ina iso?
U mimaanay saw ko demak ni ama no miso?
U sava haw no miso cira?
Caay, o cavay no sava to vavainayan no mako.
english: No, he is my younger brother’s friend.

ami: U kaka to vavahian haw no miso cira?
Caay, o sava to vavahian no mako cira.
english: No, she is my younger sister.

ami: Papina saw ko tamdaw no loma' no heni?
english: How many people in their family?

ami: Lalima ko tamdaw no loma' no heni.
english: There are five people in their family.

ami: Papina saw ko wawa no loma' namo?
english: How many children in your family?
There are four children in our family.

ami: Papina saw ko sava no miso?
english: How many younger siblings do you have?

ami: Awaay ko sava no mako to vavainayan, tatolo ko sava to vavahian.
english: I don’t have any younger brothers, but I have three younger sisters.

ami: Papina saw ko kaka no miso?
english: How many older siblings do you have?
I don’t have any older siblings.
How many siblings do you have?

ami: Hay, o kaka no mako cira.
Sienaw ko remiad, pinanomi to vaedetay a nanom.
english: It’s a bit cold, so you need to drink more warm water.

ami: Caledes ko remiad, adihayen ko nipinanom.
english: It’s a bit hot, so you need to drink more water.

ami: Mamaan saw ko remiad i hekal?

english: The sun is bright and remember to wear sunscreen.

ami: Mamaan saw ko remiad i hekal?
Sikotemto, awaay a mamelaw ko cidal.
english: There are a lot of clouds but no sun in the sky.

ami: A mamaan hakiya ko remiad anocila?
Awaay ko cidal, sikotem, tataang ko vali anocila.
english: It will be cloudy and windy but not sunny tomorrow.

ami: Namamaan saw ko remiad itiya a remiadan?
english: How was the weather that day?

ami: Sienaw itiya a remiad, kasiparakto to a tahekal.
english: It was a bit cold and you needed to wear a jacket when you went outside.

ami: A mamaan hakiya ko remiad itiya i pahanhanan?
english: How’s the weather on the weekend?
It will be sunny on the weekend.

ami: A oradan hakiya itiya a remiadan?
english: Will it be rainy that day?

ami: Cahedalan ko remiad itiya a remiad, caay kaoradan.
english: It will have no rain and be sunny that day.

ami: A oradan hakiya itiya a remiadan?
english: Will it be rainy that day?

ami: Hay, a maorad i tiya a remiad.
english: Yes, it will be rainy that day.

ami: Masaterepto ko orad, masadak to ko cidal.
english: The rain stops and the sun comes out.
It is raining and I don’t have an umbrella with me.

ami: Caay to kaoradan anini, a maorad i herek no lahok, kasicacevaren to a tahekal.
english: It is not raining now, but it will be rainy in the afternoon, so you need to bring an umbrella when you go out.

ami: A sienaway hakiya ko kasienawan no anocila a mihcaan?
english: Will it be very cold in winter next year?

ami: Hay, a sienaaw i kasienawan no anocila a mihecaan, tongalento ko nikasivodoy.
english: Yes, it will be very cold in winter next year, so you need to put on extra layers.

ami: A caledes haw i kalalodan no anini a mihecaan?
english: Will it be very hot in summer this year?

ami: Hay, a caledes i kalalodan, adihayen ko nipinanom.
english: Yes, it will be very hot and you need to drink more water.

ami: Hay, maolah kako to kacanglahan, dihekoway ko remiad.
english: I like spring because the weather is warm.

ami: Caay kaolah kako to kasariwsiwan, adihay ko valiyos i kasariwsiwan.
english: I don’t like autumn because there are lots of typhoons in autumn.
I forgot to bring the textbook.

ami: Tatosa han no mita a mimelaw.
english: I will share it with you.
I forgot to bring the eraser.

ami: Mapawan haw kiso a mikerid to sisapisorit?
english: Do you forget to bring your pen?

ami: Hay, pacaliwi isaw kako to sapisorit no miso?
english: Yes, can you lend me a pen?

ami: A o maan saw ko sakalahok no miso?
english: What would you like for lunch?

ami: A o maan saw ko sakalavi no miso?
english: What would you like for dinner?

ami: Na o maan saw ko sakaranam no miso?
english: What did you have for breakfast?

ami: Na o litaol ko nikaen no mako.
Na o maan saw ko sakalahok no miso?
english: What did you have for lunch?

ami: Na o titi no ayam ko nikaen no mako.
Ka iso ko ayaw, kilim hanaw to ako kiso anosawni.
english: You go first and I will catch up later.

ami: Naay, ka o codad ko ayawen no mita a micolo'.
english: No, we have to carry books first.

ami: Namisolac to haw kiso to wadis?
Caay hen, misovaway hen kako to kaysing.
english: Not yet. I am doing the dishes.
Did you rinse out your mouth?
Yes, I rinsed out my mouth.

ami: Namisovaw to haw kiso to kaysing?
Kiya caay saw kamamanaw to kamay kiso?
english: Why didn’t you wash your hands?
I will wash my hands later.
What were you doing just now?
I went to meet the teacher.

ami: A mimaan saw kiso i herek namicodad?
english: What are you going to do after school?

ami: A kakeror sato kako a taloma'.
A mimaan saw cira i herek namicodad?
english: What is she doing after school?
She is going to go dancing.

ami: Aniwaw, i loma' to haw kiso?
Aniwaw, i loma' to haw kiso?
Awaay i loma' ci Aniw, ci Lipay kako. A mimaan saw? Sasowal hanaw to ako ci Aniw ano taloma'.
english: Aniw is not at home. I am Lipay. What can I do for you? I will let him know when he comes back.

ami: Vayiaw, ci Tipos aci Aniw kami, padangi kami a mivohat to panan!
english: Grandma, we are Tipus and Aniw, please open the door for us.

ami: Ci Poyar kako, tayniyay kako a mikilim ci Laisan.
english: I am Puyar, I am here for Lais.

ami: Vayiaw, tayniyay kako a miliso' i tisowan.
english: Grandma, I am here to see you.

ami: Matenesto a caay katayni kiso, maoron to aca kako i tisowan.
english: You haven’t been here for a long time. I missed you so much.
Aniw, I am here to play with you.
Come on in! I have been waiting for you for a long time.

ami: Tanamen may! o nipaloma no mako a vonga kiniyan.
english: This is the sweet potato I grow. Try it!
The sweet potato is so sweet.

ami: Kati! kaenen saw! U nipalomaan no mako a losay kiniyan.
english: Come here! These are the fruits I grow. You should try it.

ami: Kamaro' ! Kaenen saw! U nipalomaan no mako a taviras kiniyan.
english: Take a seat! You should try some organic corn that I grow.

ami: Emm ! U roma ko sicedam nina taviras haw.
english: Wow! The corn tastes so sweet.

ami: Mangalay haw kiso a kemaen to kama?
A caay hen kako kakemaen to kama, ka o linko hanaw.
english: I can’t eat oranges. I will have some apples instead.

ami: Mangalay haw kiso a kemaen to piyang?

english: Sure, I like it very much.

ami: Pohci'ay hen no kako ko losay to sapakaen i tisowan.
english: Let me peel the fruit for you.

ami: Ay haw! Tanosalang saan kina losay.
english: Thank you. This fruit is so juicy.
I will bring you some water.

ami: Saadihayen ko nikaen, adihay ko nicacakan no mako to sinavel.
english: Enjoy yourself. I cooked a lot of dishes.

ami: Ay! Savangsis saan, saaleso' aca a kaenen.
english: Oh! It smells good and looks delicious.

ami: Dopohi a kemaen, adihay hen itini.
english: Enjoy yourself. There is a lot more.
I’ll make myself at home then.

ami: Dopohi a kemaen, adihay hen itini.
english: Enjoy yourself. There are plenty here.

ami: Adihayto ko nikaen no mako, hamanan to.
english: I ate a lot and couldn’t eat any more.

ami: A hakolongen no pasevana'ay kamo a talalotok i anini a remiad.
english: I will take you to the mountains today.

ami: Tanolikes saan i lotok sa ci ina.
english: Mom says that there are lots of mosquitoes in the mountains.

ami: A hakolongen no pasevana'ay kamo a talaomah i anini a remiad.
english: I will take you to the fields.

ami: A tayra haw kita a mikali to sera?
english: Are we going to loosen the soil?

ami: A hakolongen no pasevana'ay kita a tayra tarawadaw.
english: Teacher will take us to the riverside.

ami: A hakolongen no pasevana'ay kita a talalotok.
english: Teacher will take us to the mountains today.

ami: A tayra haw kita i tarawadaw?
english: Are we going to the riverside today?

ami: Caay, a keriden kita no pasevana'ay a talalotok.
english: No, our teacher is going to take us to the mountains.
Are we going to the mountains today?
No, we are going to the fields.

ami: Pasevana'ay, a o maan saw ko mamelawen no mita i tarawadaw?
english: Teacher, what are we going to see at the riverside?

ami: A tayra kita a mimelaw to veded.
english: We are going to see dragonflies.

ami: Pasevana'ay, a o maan saw ko mamelawen no mita a talalotok?
english: Teacher, what are we going to see in the mountains?

ami: A tayra kita a mimelaw to adipapang.
english: We are going to see butterflies.

ami: A mimaan saw kita a talaomah?
english: What are we going to do in the fields?

ami: A talaoamh a mimelaw kita to nipalomaan a taviras, arawi haw! silalonah, sikaketi yo!
english: We are going to see the corn we grow in the fields, but you need to be aware of the ants and bees.

ami: Pasevana'ay, a tayra haw kita i saowac a midangoy?
english: Teacher, are we going to swim in the river?

ami: Caay, a tayra kita mimelaw to veded.
english: No, we are going to see dragonflies.

ami: Pasevana'ay, a talaomah haw kita a paloma to dateng?
english: Teacher, are we going to grow some vegetables in the fields?

ami: A tayra kami mikali to sera.
english: We are going to loosen the soil today.

ami: Anini hen kako a makamelaw to maoripay a veded.
english: Today is the first time I see real living dragonflies.

ami: Hovaw! ay! Maolah kako to adipapang, savangcal saan.
english: Yeh! Wow! I love butterflies. They are very beautiful.

ami: Caay, ka o adipapang kiraan, o odal kiraan.
english: Those are not butterflies. They are bees.

ami: Kaitini to a misamelamelaw, aka katayra i raay yo!
english: Come here and take a look. Don’t go too far!

ami: Hay, a caay katayra i raay kami.
english: Got it, we won’t go anywhere too far.

ami: Aka kavekac, naonen ko rakat, matolo'a.
english: Don’t run and walk slowly lest you fall down.
I want to see them right away.

ami: Makamaan saw kiso a tara i taloan?
english: How do you go to the block-house?

ami: Makakarireng kako a tara i taloan.
Makamaan saw cira a tara i paisingan?
english: How does he go to the hospital?

ami: Rakaten nira a tara i paisingan.
Makamaan saw kiso a tara i Peng-ho?
english: How do you go to Penghu?

ami: Makahikoki kako a tara i Peng-ho.
english: I go to Penghu by plane.

ami: Makamaan saw kiso a tara i Peng-ho?
english: How do you go to Penghu?

ami: Makalonan kako a tara i Peng-ho.
english: I go to Penghu by boat.

ami: Makamaan saw ci Panay a tara i cacodadan?
english: How does Panay go to school?
Panay goes to school by train.

ami: Makamaan saw ci Kacaw a tara i kyokay?
english: How does Kacaw go to church?

ami: Makavatikar ci Kacaw a tala kyokay.
english: Kacaw goes to church by bicycle.
Do you go to school by MRT?
No, I go to school by bus.
Do you go to school by bicycle?
Yes, I go to school by bicycle.

ami: Makakawtye haw kiso a tara Takao?
english: Do you go to Kaohsiung by High Speed Rail?

ami: Hay, makakawtye kako a tala Takao.
english: Yes, I go to Kaohsiung by High Speed Rail.

ami: U silamalay haw anosa makahikoki kiso a tara Taytong?
english: Are you going to Taitung by train or by plane?

ami: Makahikoki kako, ki'ayawen no hikoki ko silamalay.
english: I will take the plane because it is faster than the train.

ami: A makavaso haw kiso a tala kiyokay anosa a parakat to karireng kiso?
english: Are you going to drive to the church or take the bus?

ami: A parakat kako to karireng a tala kyokay, mangalav ko nikacalowayan a makavaso.
english: I will drive to the church because it is more convenient than the bus.

ami: Hacowa saw ko nikararaay no patiyamay ato loma' namo?
english: Is the market close to your house?

ami: Caay kangata isaw, makaotovay to kako a tara i patiyamay.
english: No, it is not, so I always ride the motorcycle to the market.

ami: Mangangata haw ko yoving ato cacodadan?
english: Is the post office close to the school?
Yes, it is within walking distance.

ami: Mangangata haw ko kakaenan ato pangiroan?
english: Is the restaurant close to the station?

ami: I kaepodan a pangiroan, pasatimolen ko rakat, lima a sasoritan hakiya ko nirakatan tangsa to ko kakatayraan.
english: It only takes five minutes after you walk out of the station.

ami: Mangalay kako a tayra a miliso' i tisowan.
english: I would like to visit you.

ami: Sidemak hen kako awaay i loma', lica hanawto!
english: I am out today. How about another day?

ami: Silawaday hakiya kiso anocila? I herek no lahok a tayra isaw kako.
english: Then, are you available tomorrow? I’ll visit you tomorrow afternoon.

ami: Kapah to! hay, i loma' kako a mitala i tisowan.
english: Sure, I will wait for you at home.

ami: Kapah to haw a miloinen no mako? Hangay mangaay a soriten no mako isaw.
english: Would you mind if I do the voice recording? I would like to keep a record.
Would you mind if I do the video recording?

ami: Caay kasalongan a melawen kako, caay hen aca pilisimet to alili, hamanan anini.
english: No, I am plain and the warehouse hasn’t been tidied up yet.

ami: Ka o nipisiyasing hanaw no mako.
english: Then I will just take photos.

ami: Aray han no mako kiso to nipapiliso' a mipalita i tisowan.
english: Thank you for accepting the interview.

ami: Aymaan saw! A o maan ko papalitaan no miso?
english: You are welcome. What would you like to know?

ami: Yo masakapah hen kiso, na o maan saw ko demaken?
english: What do you do when you are young?

ami: Namalakincalay kako i naayaw, nika misawad to kako anini.
english: I was a police officer but I am retired now.
Then, are you working at the moment?

ami: I niyaro' haw a maro' ko wawa no miso?
english: Do your kids live in the tribe too?

ami: Caay, i tokay ko aro' no wawa no mako isaw.
english: No, my kids are all living in the city.

ami: Iso to a cacay haw ko maro'ay itini?
english: Then, do you live by yourself?

ami: Irato ko nipahavay no mako to waco ato ayam, o tamadaway to no loma' no mako ko heni isaw.
english: I also keep a dog and a bird. They are my family.

ami: Ira ko nipahavayan no mako to nani, ira ko pacavayay, caay to kasacacay isaw.
english: I have a cat too. I won’t get bored with the company of my pet.

ami: Ira ko papalitaan no kako to paysin to no sakay piadopan.
english: I would like to ask you about the taboos of hunting.

ami: Caay kahacowa ko nikavana'an no mako, iraan hanaw to o nikavana'an no mako ko sapacaov i tisowan.
english: I don’t know much about that, but I will tell you everything I know.

ami: Sipaysin haw kamo to sapiadop a sarepet?
english: Do you have any taboos about hunting weapons?

ami: Caay pisolol kami a tevingen no vavahi ko sapiadop a rarepetan.
english: Our hunting weapons are untouchable to women.

ami: Kapah to haw a papihakolongen ko vavahi a miadop?
english: Then, can women go hunting together?

ami: Akaa, raecos ko vavahi a miadop.
english: No, women cannot go hunting either.

ami: Kacaw, picakayi to viciw, awaay to ko viciw no loma'.
english: Kacaw, our home is out of rice wine, please go and buy some.

ami: Hamanan picakay! Siosaw hen to cacay a sinatowikan i aniva.
english: There is still one bottle left in the kitchen, so there is no need to buy one!

ami: Caay kadengay ko cacay a sinatowik, tosaen aca ko nipicakay.
english: One bottle is not enough for me, go and buy two more back.

ami: A micakay kako to viciw, sinipacakay haw namo?
english: I am looking for rice wine. Do you have any rice wine?

ami: Irato isaw! A pinaen saw ko nipicakay no miso?
english: Yes! How many bottles do you need?

ami: Tosaen, a micakay aca kako to cacay a tavo no velac.
english: I want two bottles and a pack of rice.

ami: Ini ko velac, sicacakayen hen haw kiso?
english: Here is the rice, what else do you need?

ami: A micakay aca kako to litaol, sinipacakay haw kamo?
english: I want some eggs too, do you have some?

ami: Awaay to ko papacakayen to litaol niyam.

english: I want to buy some clothes.

ami: U mamaanay saw ko kangalayan no miso?
english: What kind of clothes do you like?

ami: U maposotay a ledong ko cakayen no mako.
english: I want to buy the clothes with short sleeves.

ami: Mamaan saw kira lahngangay a vodoyan?
Siosaw hen kami to vohcalay ato karacingay.
english: We have white and blue ones too.

ami: Pavelien kako tira karacingay a vodoy.
english: Please give me the clothes in blue.

ami: Kacaw, natalacowaay saw kiso inasawni? Milaylayay haw kiso to tireng?
english: Kacaw, where have you been just now? Did you go exercising?

ami: Caay, namipadang kako a pacakay to dateng ni vayi.
english: No, I went grocery shopping for my grandma.

ami: Namahaen haw! silawad haw kiso to lavii' ? mamaan saw a mahkolong kita a malavi ?
english: No wonder! Are you available at night? Would you like to have a meal with me?

ami: Awaay ko lawad, a tayra kako a micakay to vodoy.
english: No, I want to buy some clothes.
Then, I will go with you.

ami: Kapah haw kiso, pinaan saw kina dateng?
english: Hello, how much is this bunch of vegetables?

ami: Cacay a kamel tosa a polo' ko aca.
english: The vegetables are $20 for a bunch.
How much are these sweet potatoes?

ami: Cacay a dadoy no vonga tolo a polo' ko aca.
english: Sweet potatoes are thirty dollars for a pound.

ami: Pavelien kako to tosa a kamel no dateng ato cacay a dadoyan no vonga.
english: Please give me two bunches of vegetables and a pound of sweet potatoes.

ami: Kacawaw, mapawan kako a mikerid to sapisorit, kapah haw kiso a pacaliw i takowan?
english: Kacaw, I forgot to bring my pen. Can you lend me one?

ami: Mahaen kako, o ni Panay kiniyan.
english: I don’t have one either. This is Panay’s.

ami: Pacaliwi hen aca kako? Sani a panokasen to no mako kiso.
english: Can you lend me the pen for a second? I will return to you immediately.

ami: Aray, aray han to ci Panay.
english: Thank you and thank Panay for me.

ami: U maan saw ko kangalayan no miso?
A panokas kako tina tosaay a codad.
english: I want to return these two books.

ami: Hay, ira hen haw ko kangalayen?
english: No problem and what else do you need?

ami: A micaliw aca kako tina toloay a codad.
english: I would like to borrow these three books.

ami: Haenento! aka kapawan a panokas itiya i sakatolo a remiadan.
english: Sure and remember to return them after three days.

ami: Caay hen panokas kiso to savoric no mako.
english: You haven’t returned me the eraser.

ami: Icowa to aca saw ko savoric mako?
english: Then, why is my eraser missing?

ami: Nacaay haw pacaliwi no miso i ci Kacawan?
english: Did you lend it to Kacaw?

ami: Nakeno! Palitaaw may no mako cira.
english: I don’t know. I will go and ask her.

ami: Pacaliway aca no mako ko savoric i tisowan.
english: I will lend you my eraser first.

ami: Panay, o nipacaliwan haw no miso kina paraketo i ci Kacawan?
english: Panay, did Kacaw lend you this coat?

ami: Caay, o nicakayan ni ina ako to hamakoan.
english: No, my mom bought it for me.

ami: U malecaday ko paraketo ni Kacaw ato no miso.
english: Kacaw’s coat is the same as yours.

ami: U mohetingay ko paraketo nira, caay kalecad ko kolit niyam.
english: His coat is black, so our colors are different.

ami: Panay, namicaliw haw kiso to pida i ci Kacawan?
english: Panay, did you borrow money from Kacaw?

ami: Hay, ka o panokas isaw kako anini, nika, mapawan kako a mikerid to pida.
english: Yes, I was supposed to return to him today, but I forgot to bring the money.

ami: A hacowato to saw kiso a panokas?
english: Then, when will you return the money?
I will return to him tomorrow.

ami: Hay, akoay to ko semowalay i ci Kacawan.
english: Okay, I will tell Kacaw for you.

ami: A o taerev ko sapitama' to kalavaw, a o erid ko sapiteker to tikolac, kiya o marocekay isaw.
english: It is correct to catch mice through rangay and catch bamboo partridges through qjiulang.

ami: Araw mahaen haw, moraraw kako hani, araci' awaay ko nilepel no mako.
english: No wonder! I am mistaken and that’s why I cannot catch any of them.

ami: Pasevana'ay to no mako kiso, ano maanen ko nipisanga' tiya tosaan a tatekeran.
english: Then I will teach you how to set up these two traps.

ami: Ayi! Piolah waro! Ano mahaen a awaay aca haw ko nilepelan no mako.
english: Great! I will be able to catch the prey in the future.

ami: Tarakawto ko rengos no omah, pialai to kakawit i alili, tayra kita i omah.
english: The grass in the fields is too tall. Go to the warehouse to take the sickle and let’s go to the fields.

ami: Icowa to saw kira nipatelian a kakawit?
I tapiingan no vasolan, comod han no miso i alili, mamelaw to.
english: It is next to the round basket. You will see it when you enter the warehouse.

ami: Pisinanoti a miala, matavala, matalem ko kakawit.
english: Be careful and don’t get hurt. The sickle is very sharp.

ami: Aka piripa' to nipatekeran no mako.
Icowa saw ko mipatekeran no miso?
Itila i sasa nira kilangan ko nipateker no mako.
english: My trap is under that tree.

ami: Irato ko nipatektek to mamelawen, kiya mavana' to kako i sacowaan ko nipaeridan no mako.
english: I make a mark here, so I know where my trap is.

ami: U vovo kinian, i lilis no saowac ko nipateli niyam a mivoting.
english: This is a fish trap which we put beside the river for fishing.

ami: Awaay ko nipavovo niyam itila, o nipacemot ko sapivoting niyam.
english: We don’t have any fish traps there, so we catch fish with a fishing rod.

ami: Nacaay hen pacemot kako, paseva'en kako anoroma?
english: I have never used a fishing rod before, would you mind teaching me next time?

ami: Hayi! Mahelokonga kita a pacemot to voting i romaan a remiad.
english: Sure! Let’s go fishing together next time.

ami: Pasevana'ay to no mako kiso a misanga' to vovo anoroma.
english: I will teach you how to make a fish trap next time.

ami: Mananowang to ko sapacemot no miso, simikaenay to haw no voting? soloten to anini.
english: Your fishing rod is moving. Isn’t the fish on the hook? Pull it up!

ami: Akahenay, pihaceng ko nikalinalin no lonan. Itini kako a misolot to sapacemot, kaira kiso a mipadang a patodod to cadiway i takowan.
english: Wait, the ship is rolling heavily. I am here to pull the fishing rod and you should go there to grab me the net.

ami: Pasaynien ko nipisolot to voting i takowan, padangay no mako kiso a misolot.
english: Pull the fish to my side and I will help you pull it up

ami: Hovaw! Masevek ko nipivotingan anini a remiad, matoemes to ko vovo ita.
english: Great! It is a bumper crop today with full fish baskets.

ami: Sakalamkamaw no mita a taloma', pavatisay to ko alomanay.
english: Let’s go back immediately and share it with everyone.

ami: Aka to pisalama, Kalamkamen a maro' i aaro'an.
english: Stop playing and quickly sit in your seat.

ami: Sakalima a remiad namilipay anini, a pahanhan to anocila, mahkolonga kita a talamiholol!
english: It's Friday today, we have a day off tomorrow. Let's go out and play together!
Great! Let's go to the riverside.

ami: Sakapina to a remiad namilipay anocila?
english: What day will it be tomorrow?

ami: Sakatolo a remiad namilipay anocila, a mimali kami anocila i herek no lahok!
english: Tomorrow will be Wednesday. Let's go play ball tomorrow afternoon!

ami: A mimaan saw kiso anocila a davak?
english: What will you be doing tomorrow morning?

ami: U pilipayan anocila, a talakiyokay kako aci ina ako.
english: Tomorrow will be Sunday, I will be going to church with my mom.

ami: A mota kako, a talatatayi'an kako.
english: I feel like vomiting. I need to go to the restroom.

ami: Pasevana'ay, adada ko tiya no mako, a talatatayi'an kako.
english: Teacher, I have a stomachache. I need to go to the restroom.

ami: Mangaay haw kako a talamisovaw to kamay ako?
english: May I go wash my hands?

ami: A pahanhanto namicodad, a tatayra aca anosani.
english: It's almost time for class to end. Wait a little longer.

ami: Pasevana'ay, adada ko tangal no mako, a pahanhan kako i herek no lahok.
english: Teacher, I have a severe headache. I need to take a sick leave in the afternoon.

ami: Hayi, piarawi to haw ano taloma'.
english: Okay, take care and go home.

ami: Pasevana'ay a pahanhan kako i sakacacay namilipay a remiad, a paising kako.
english: Teacher, I need to take a sick leave next Monday. I have to see a doctor.

ami: Hayi, sakapah han to ko tireng.
Adadaay ko tiyad nira, i tatayi'an cira.
english: She has a stomachache. She's in the restroom.

ami: Pasevana'ay, adadaay ko takolaw ni Kacaw, a pahanhan cira anini.
english: Teacher, Kacaw has a sore throat. She took a sick leave today.

ami: Kasemowal may to orip no miso.
Ci Komod ko ngangan no mako, moktep ko mihecaan no kako anini.
english: My name is Noami Kumud, and I’m 10 years old.

ami: Ci Komod Looh ko ngangan no mako.
U maanan a vinacadan no wawa kiso?
english: What ethnic group are you from?

ami: U Yincomin amin haw ko lalavo no loma' no miso?
english: Are all your family members indigenous?

ami: Hayi, o Pangcah amin ko lalavo no loma' no niyam.
english: Yes, my whole family is Amis.

ami: U Yincomin amin haw ko lalavo no loma' no miso?
english: Are all your family members indigenous?

ami: Caay, o Pangcah ci ama ako, o Holam ko ina no mako.
english: No, my father is Amis, and my mother is Han Chinese.

ami: U nima saw a wawa kiso?
U wawa ni Mayaw Lahok kako.
U wama iso haw kiraan? Pina to ko mihcaan nira?
english: Is that your father? How old is he?

ami: Enem a polo' to ko mihcaan nira.
U wama iso haw kiraan? Pina to ko mihcaan nira?
english: Is that your father? How old is he?

ami: Caay, o kalas no niyaro' no niyam cira, walo a polo' to ko mihcaan nira.
english: No, he is an elder of our tribe. He is 80 years old.

ami: Pina to ko mihcaan ni kaka no miso?
Savaw to walo to ko mihcaan ni kaka no mako.
Hacowa saw ko pikikaka no kaka iso itisowan?
english: Is your brother much older than you?

ami: Lima a mihcaan ko laed no niyam.
Caay a patekenan ira ko sepat a polo' a kong-fen kako.
Matenes to kita caay kasasoaraw, mavatacay to kiso?
english: I haven’t seen you in a while. Have you grown taller?

ami: Hayi, cacay a patekenan ira ko tolo a polo' a kong-fen kako.
Icowa saw, patelacay ko nipimelaw no miso.
Hayi, tolo a polo' a kong-cin kako anini.
A tayra kako i pangkongse a mikilim to pasevana'ay.
english: I’m going to the office to see the teacher.

ami: A tayra mivalah to tatoni' cira.
english: He’s going to throw away the trash.

ami: I dadangoyan cira, a madademec a midangoy cira anosani.
english: He’s at the swimming pool. He’s going to compete in a swimming competition later.

ami: Icowa saw ci Panay? a mamacavi' a mavekac cira anosani.
english: Where is Panay? She’s going to compete in a running competition later.

ami: Ira i li-tang cira, angangen ako cira.
english: She’s in the auditorium. I’ll go call her.

ami: Ta Mahkolanga kita a tayra i vavekacan!
english: Let’s go to the playground together.

ami: A tayra hen kako a micakay to sakalahok, kilim han to no mako kiso anosani.
english: I’ll go buy lunch first, and then I’ll meet you later.

ami: Ta Mahkolonga kita a mivawa to tavo!
english: Let’s carry the lunch boxes together!

ami: Pikilimi to tao, a tayra hen kako a mikilim to pasevana'ay.
english: You find someone else, I’m going to find the teacher.

ami: Kacaw, a madademec to yakiw haw anini?
english: Is Kacaw competing in croquet today?

ami: Caay, a madadec a mihatevo cira.
english: No, he’s competing in high jump.

ami: Yo piondokayan a ira kiso haw a madademec?
english: Will you compete in the sports day?

ami: Hayi, a macacavi' a mavekac kako.
Yo piondokayan a ira kiso haw a madademec?
english: Will you compete in the sports day?

ami: Ira kako a madademec to coy-ciw.
Yo piondokayan a mimaan saw kita itiya a remiad?
english: What will we do in the sports day?
We will compete in tug of war.

ami: I piondokayan a pacakay haw kita to kakenen?
english: Will we sell food at the sports day?

ami: Caay, a o mali ko sapacakay no mita.

english: Congratulations on getting first place! You’re amazing!

ami: I loma' to haw ci vayi?
Ira to, mavoti'ay cira i kakavotian.
english: Yes, she’s sleeping in her room.
