english: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

ami: I piliyasan niyam, araw takawen no tao ko otovay, maanen aca, dakaw sato kami to vaso a miliyas.
english: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

ami: Tangasato kami anini i Taypak, matepaay to hakiya ko otovay ni vaki ?
english: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don’t know if my uncle’s motorcycle has been found.

ami: Nano wawa, na i Rinahem ko loma' niyam, micodad sato, tayraen i Tawyen a malinah, i tokatokayan sato a maorip.
english: When we were young, our family lived in Rinahem. After I started school, we moved to Taoyuan and have been living in the city ever since.

ami: Micodad sato kako i Tasiye, o serangawan no Yincomin, ko nitotocan no mako a minanam, o sakavana' to nikasaromaroma a serangawan no i Taywanay a yaanay ko aro' a vinacadan.
english: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

ami: Sisa, a taloma' kako ato kaka to vavainayan i pipantangan nina mihca mangalay a miliso' to kalas no niyaro', mangalay a misapinang to serangawan no orip.
english: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

ami: Walo a polo' to ko mihcaan no matoasay, nika matiya i terongay hen ko mihcaan a melawen.
english: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

ami: Pina saw ko nikavana'an no miso to sowal no romaan a niyaro'? mavana' cira a semowal tono Ripon, no Teroko ato no Ngayngay.
english: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Teruku, as well as Atayal, Hakka and Ngayngay.

ami: Palita han no mako cira, araw nano wawa mavana'to to sowal no Ripon, siramod sa o vavahi no Teroko, i nikadademak aloman ko cavay nira to Ngayngay, namahaen hati:la sato ko kavana'an nira to romaan a sowal.
english: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Teruku, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

ami: I nipiliso' niyam a masasowal, adihay ko nipasevana' ni vaki to kakawaw tono sakay pivotingan, piadopan a rayrayan.
english: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

ami: Kanahato caay katesek ko nikavana'an niyam to nipisaheci ni vaki, nika, loingen niyam to soci, hangay liyawan no niyam a misapinang a mitengil i loma'.
english: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

ami: Yo wawa hen kami nahacowa a mavana' to serangawan no tireng, mangodo aca a kavana'an no tao to wawa no Pangcah.
english: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

ami: Adihay ko nikavana'an to serangawan no toas, mangalev ko nikariang a malawawa no Pangcah, o masacidekay, o kasenengan ko vinacadan no mita.
english: The more I know, the more I feel that being a ’Amis is unique and something to be proud of.

ami: I sangsangdev nina remiad, a taloma' ko sava to vavainayan.
english: My younger brother is going home this evening.

ami: Tayra i iciva kako aci vayi a micakay to ayam, a micacak to aleso'ay a sakalavi a pakaen to vavainayan a sava.
english: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

ami: Mitaeliv kami to pacakayay to dateng, adihay ko loengelay a dateng i nipatadaan.
english: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

ami: Sinicakay kami to incay, koleto ato nincing.
english: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

ami: Ira i teparay a pacakayay to losay a tawki sowal saan : "U nipacakayan no mako to paringad ato ropas sicedamay yo! picakayi saw atodi!"
english: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

ami: Cakay sato kami to paringad ato ropas.
Mitaeliv kami to pacakayay to titi, sowal sa kira tawki: A o maan saw ko cakayen no miso? tataang siheci aca kina ayam anini, tolo a patekenan ko cacayay.
english: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

ami: Matekesen ci vayi, keloli saw atodi saan a mipalita tira tawkian.
english: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

ami: Caay to katekes isaw saan kira tawki, awaay to ko kakelolan.
english: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

ami: Katayni i takowan a micakay to voting, saan kira i teparay a tawki, caay katekes, tataak aca ko voting no mako saan a semowal.
english: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

ami: Herek saan kami a micakay to ayam ato voting, taloma' sato cacay a sapadan ko nipatada to nicacakan to sinavelan.
english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

ami: Matenes ko nipitala, araw toeman to ko remiad.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

ami: Patelay ko sava to vavainayan, sikavahalan no kontay a caay aca pihivang saan, a pakocila to lalipayan kiya a taloma' isaw.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

ami: Sowal sa ci vayi adihay ko nicacakan, katien ko alomanay a patayni a kemaen.
english: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

ami: Aloman ko nitakosan niyam to cavay, komoday no mita a miseka to nisakalavian.
english: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

ami: Ira ko kapaot no mako ci Kacaw han ko ngangan, hinapawapawan a mikerit ko lalosidan nira.
english: I have a classmate named Kacaw, he often forgets to bring things.

ami: I nipicodad sato, micaliw cira to sapisorit, savoric ansa o sasasoritan to teparay a kapotan.
english: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

ami: Kinacacay, kinatosa, kinatolo, pacaliwanto no alomanay to maan i ciraan.
english: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

ami: Nika, siraecosay a wayway cira, namicaliw to lalosidan caay to panokas to nicaliwan.
english: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

ami: Tonamahaen, awaay to ko pacaliway no alomanay to lalosidan no heni i ciraan.
english: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

ami: Cacay a remiad, mahekolong kami o alomanay a tayra i omaomahan a miholol.
english: One day, we all went on an outing together.

ami: I vatad no lalan, alenih ci Kacaw, nika mapawan cira to sailos a tatipelok.
english: On the way, Kacaw wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

ami: Micaliw cira to sailos i kapot. Nika, awaay ko nikerida niyam saan a pacaov i ciraan.
english: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn't bring them either.

ami: Taletangicto ci Kacaw a makatengil, macalivat a semowal cira, kiya caay saw pacaliw to sailos i takowan saan.
english: Kacaw burst into tears. He said angrily, why don't everyone lend me toilet paper!

ami: Pacaov han to no kapot cira, caay kiso pikerid to no tirengay a laosidan kiyami? Iri, nipicaliwan a lalosidan i tisowan nahacowa saw kiso a panokas!
english: The classmate told him, because you didn't bring it yourself, and you wouldn't return the things lent to you!

ami: Pakocila a micodad, maratar ci Kacaw a i cacodadan, panokasen ni Kacaw amin ko nicaliwan to kapot.
english: The next day at school, Kacaw arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

ami: Sololen kako saan ci Kacaw to kapot nira, a mikerid to kako to laosidan no tireng i nalikolan saan, a miaray aca to nikangaay no kapot a pacaliw i ciraan.
english: kacaw apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

ami: U miadopay no niyaro' ko ama no mako.
english: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

ami: Yo wawa hen kako, yo tahekal ci ama aci vaki, sinirepet to hawan ato kowang ko heni.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

ami: Tangelal sa hen ko remiad, siniawit to tama' ko heni a taloma'.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

ami: Yo roma sa o vavoy no lotok, yo roma sa o rapic, alamaanan ira ko tolok.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

ami: I loma' ko heni a mikilac to tama' to sapavatis to laloma'an.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

ami: Miocil kako ci amaan, mangalay a mihakolong ci amaan a miadop.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

ami: Itiyaaw to a mihakolong ano matoas to kiso saan ci ama.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

ami: U teker ko sapiadop no vavainay, mavana' ko heni a misanga' to talakal, to erid ato taerev.
english: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

ami: Mavana' ci ama ako a misateker, o sapiteker to tolok ko matoniay saan, a sameteken no mita a mimelaw ko narakatan no aadopen, solinay paconek han i narakatan no aadopen a pateli.
english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

ami: Makalah kako a matoas saan, kiya a hakolongen no matoasay a miadop, saremiad sato kako a minanam a misanga' to tatekeran, solinay, sinikalepelan to aadopen ko nisanga'an no mako a teker.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

ami: Melaw sa ci ama i takowan, Sowal sa : A o tatadaanay a miadopay kiso i romaan a remiad.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

ami: Matoas to kako anini, caelayen no mako ko pana' a mihakolong ci amaan a tayra a miadop.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

ami: Taloma' sa i niyaro' kilacen niyam ko tama' a pavatis to laloma'an.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

ami: Sowal sa ci ama, "A mivetik kita to nipalemed no kawas to nikarahid no mita a ira ko sakataloma' a tama'."
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

ami: Namaotang kako a talacacodadan i nadavak.
english: I was late for school this morning.

ami: Mapawan kako a sikavang, natala i cacodadan.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

ami: Awaawa ko nikerid no mako to maamaan.
english: I didn’t bring anything with me.

ami: I namicodad, mahkolong kako ato kapot a mimelaw to codad.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

ami: I pisekingan, pacaliwan no kapot kako to sapisorit ato savoric.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

ami: Pasowal sato ko pasevan'ay itakowan, "akaa to kaotang, karatar to a lomowad haw!"
english: The teacher told me, “Wake up earlier next time and don’t be late again!”

ami: U sakapahay no mako a cavay ci Kacaw, o wawa: no Pangcah cira.
english: My good friend’s name is Kacaw, and he is also an Amis child.

ami: Malecavayay kami a micadad i Rinahem.
english: We study together in the Rinahem tribe.

ami: Mahkolongay to kami a mitengil to nipakongko no kalas, o mavana':ay kami a misanoPangcah.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Amis proficiently.

ami: Tarakaw, masoso aca kako, poener, makopit aca ci Kacaw.
english: I am tall and overweight, while Kacaw is short and thin.

ami: U masakapahay ci Kacaw, manay, aloman ko maolahay i ciraan.
english: Kacaw is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

ami: Miondokay ko cacodadan anini, manay adihay ko nikacacavi i cacodadan.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

ami: Ira ko mamaviyangaay, mimaliay, mavakacay, misakeroay, mipana'ay.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

ami: Namatolo' kako namavekac, tano remes sato ko tosor no mako.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

ami: Nika, lomowad kako, a taleayaw aca a mavekac.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

ami: Tano lipahak sato ko alomanay to nikatangsa no mako.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

ami: Kanahato caay kaw saayaway kako, nika lipahak kako, namaherekay to kako namadademec kiyami.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

ami: Namahkolong kako aci ama no mako a miliso' ci ama ci Kacaw i nacila.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

ami: Madokaay ko koko' ni ama ni Kacaw.
Mavohang ko vadahong no loma' saan cira i tamiyan.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

ami: Matevaday cira namakayra i vadahong, namisanga' to vadahong saan.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

ami: Siniawit ci ama to titi no rarapa ato icep, o sapaveli i ci ama ci Kacaw.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

ami: Natayra i loma' ni ama ni Kacaw kako i nacila, adihay ko nipakongko nira.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

ami: Kaw raroto kako, sowal sato ci ama ci Kacaw itakowan, mavatac to kiso, tanestes to kiso saan.
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

ami: Ano kapah to ko koko' no miso, tayni han to i loma' a miholol han ako ci ama ci Kacaw.
english: I said, When your foot gets better

ami: I 2022 a mihcaan, namilovang ko ceng-fo to madengay a cacayen ko nipangangan to ngangan no Yincomin i movinsiw.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

ami: Namipalita kako ci kolas Votingan to matenesay a madademec to ceng-fo a sacacayen ko sakasingangan i movinsiw no Yincomin.
english: I interviewed Noami Kulas, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

ami: A malitemoh kami i pihivangan, a tayra i loma' nira a mipalita i ciraan.
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

ami: Namipalita kako i ciraan, pasowal sa to nikasingangan nira, pasasoaraw aca i takowan to lalavo' no loma' ato niyaro' nira.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

ami: Palita han ako cira, kiya mangalay a misomad to ngangan, o nihaenan to a nipangangan i, caay haw kakapah?
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

ami: Sowal sato itakowan, o nisoritan a ngangan to no Holam, caay kasipinang to tadangangan nira, o roma sato ira ko mitadihangaay i ciraan to Ko-syen-sen saan, manay, o sasakemotan no tao.
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Ku Xian Sheng

ami: Sowal sato ci Kolas Voting "o sorit no Yincomin ko tadangangan no mita. U ngasaw no mita, o lalavo' no loma' no mita, o no orip to no mita, ngay alomanaloman to ko singanganay to ngangan no orip."
english: Kulas Vuting said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

ami: Namihkolong ako aci vayian talaiciva inacila, adihay ko nialaan nira to nipalomaan a dateng, ira aca ko nicacakan to aleso'ay a kakaenan no Yincomin a sapasisi to alomanay.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

ami: Maolah ko alomanay to papacakayan ni vayi, sisa, aloman ko micakayay to copel ato adeci, maolah aca mitanam to nisasinavelan nira.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

ami: Aleso' kiyami ko nisakavi'an nira to no vataan ato hakhak, ira aca ko nipalamlaman to siraw a kavi no adeci, sisa, makasanek to ko lavang a masasilsil a tayni a micakay.
english: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

ami: Ano misacacak to ci vayi, i tepar to kako a miangang to lavang. Kalamkamen a tayni a micakay to nipalomaan no niyam to tadadateng no Pangcah han ako ko micakayay.
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

ami: A mamin to ko sapacakay no niyam, sowal sato ci vayi, "iraay kiso itini a mipadang kiyami."
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, \It’s all thanks to your help.\""

ami: Pakayni i tina kalodemakan a mavana' kako to kavana'an to pinalengaw, kakaenen no Yinconmin, paso, o ngero' no pacakayay.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

ami: U mahemekay, o malemeday kako namakamelaw to nikavana'an ni vayi a misacacak to kakaenen no Pangcah.
english: Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

ami: Pito ko toki tahiraay to kako i kongkoan anini.
english: I arrived at school at seven today.

ami: Misatapng to minanam, micomod to ko singsi, sowal sa ko hanciw, katomireng! mita'ong!""
english: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

ami: Sata'angay hananay niyam ko ngiha', Nga'ay ho singsi.""
Minanam i, pakafana'en no singsi kami to sa'osi no 'Amis.
english: In class, the teacher taught us the ’Amis language of numbers.

ami: To'oren niyam ko singsi a misa'osi, miraradiw kami to no sa'osi a radiw.
english: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

ami: Adihayay ko ninanaman no mako a sowal no 'Amis.
Talakongkoan kako to romi'ami'ad, minanam kako to sowal no 'Amis to romi'ami'ad, o papatengilen ako ko ina to ninanaman ako.
english: I go to school every day, I learn the ’Amis language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

ami: Ci Asing ko ngangan no wama ako.
Ci Ipay ko ngangan no wina ako.
Moetep ko mihecaan no mako anini a mihecaan.
Cecayay ko kaka ako, ci Kolas cira, moerep ira ko cecay ko mihecaan nira anini a miheccaan.
english: I have a brother, his name is kolas, he is 11 years old.
We study in the same school.

ami: Maolahay kako ato kaka a miraradiw.
english: Both my brother and I like to sing.

ami: Maolahay kako a midangoy, ano pahanhan i, mapolongay ko loma'ay niyam a midangoy.
english: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

ami: Maolahay kako a misawidang, nga'ay a malacafay kami a miraradiw ato midangoy.
english: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

ami: Lalima ko paro no loma' niyam.
english: There are five people in our family.
There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

ami: Malacecayay ko aro' kako ato wama, wina, kaka to fa'inayan ato kaka to fafahiyan.
english: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

ami: 'akawangay ko wama ako, o kincac ko mira.
english: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

ami: Mangiliway ko wina ako, o ising ko mira.
english: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

ami: Misano'Amisan no wama kami i loma'.
english: My father speaks the ’Amis language with us at home.

ami: O kafaedetan a pahanahanan minokayay to kami talaniyaro'.
english: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

ami: Malacafayay kami malikaka tatolo a mitepa' to takola'.
english: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

ami: Maolahay kako to paro no loma' niyam.
english: I like our family very much.

ami: Malacafay kako ato wina a misalama anini.
english: I went out with my mother today.

ami: Salangdaw sanay ko kakarayan to romi'ad, cowa kasienaw cowa kafaedet ko romi'ad, saemelay ko fali.
english: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

ami: I rengorengosan kami a komaen to epang, tada diheko a mapacidal ko tireng.
english: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.

ami: Herek no lahok, kahengang to ko kakarayan.
english: In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

ami: Licayaen ako ko wina, mana kahengang sa ko kakarayan?
english: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

ami: Sowal sa ko wina, o aira ko faliyos tayni alatek.
english: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

ami: To dadaya, awaay ko o'ol i kakarayan, mahadakay to ko fo'is.
english: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

ami: Toya pinokayan a lalan, pasifo'is kako a mitolon.
english: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

ami: Nanay ca to katayni ko faliyos, hay nga'ay mahadak ho kako a misalama.
english: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

ami: I kaingid no kongkoan ko loma' ako, rakat sanay kako a talakongkoan to romi'ami'ad, rakat sanay a minokay.
english: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

ami: Cowa kata'angay ko kongkoan niyam, ca ka hakowa ko mitiliday, mananamay to kami.
english: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

ami: Masa'opo i ontofa ko kaemangay a maemin, malacafay mimali, malacafay miholol.
english: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

ami: Mikihatiyaay ko singsi malacafay tamiyanan a misalama, mahecad to laloma'an ko kongkoan niyam.
english: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

ami: Miasikay to kami to pitilidan to romi'ami'ad.
english: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

ami: Roma a tamdaw misisit to palatawan, roma a tamadaw i, miasik to paenan.
english: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

ami: Miasik ho kami to roma a aasiken i kongkoan, ma'a'isal kami to tatayalen, makakomod kami to tatayalen, mansa masolimetay, makoracay ko kongkoan niyam to romi'ami'ad.
english: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

ami: Nacila, talaniyaro' kako miliso' ci akongan.
english: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

ami: Halafin to ca kasaso'araw kami, ma'ilol to kako cingraan.
english: We haven’t seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

ami: Ma'araw ni akong kako, pakaenen nira kako to kacawas, pananomen ho nira kako to ociya.
english: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

ami: Koesanay ko nipalomaan ni akong a kacawas, 'adetay.
english: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

ami: Maolahay kako to ociya ni akong, nga'ayay a nanomen.
english: I also like grandpa’s tea, it’s tasted good too.

ami: To kalahokan to i, malacafay kako aci fofo a mitangtang to sakalahok.
english: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

ami: Kadofah ko nitangtangan ni fofo a sakalahok, ira ko foting, koko', ciyak ato comoli.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

ami: Maharek malahok, tayra kami i padatengan midateng.
english: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

ami: Adihay ko nipafelian ni fofo takowanan a konga, tali ato lokiw, hawikiden no mako a panokay sa.
english: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

ami: Liyasen to ako cangra, liyaw a romi'ad tayra sato kako miliso' cangraan, han ako.
english: I said goodbye to them and said I’d see them next time.

ami: Keriden no singsi kami tayra i pinanowangan anini, misarayaray kami i ka'ayaw no fawahan a mi'aca to paya.
english: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

ami: Micomod to i pinanowangan i, sowal sa ko singsi, "ora i ka'ayaway i, o 'aya'ayam, kaikor i, o 'one'oner, saniyaniyah han to ita a minengneng."
english: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

ami: Matalaway kako to 'oner, mansa cowa pinengneng kako to 'oner.
english: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

ami: Adihay ko ma'araway no mako a 'ayam, saefeefer sa cangra i kilakilangan, ma'araw haca ko ekong i ofang no kilang a mafoti'.
english: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

ami: Ira ko eco, efa ato lokedaw i pinanowangan, cowa ho paka'ara'araw kako tona pinanowang, paka'araw anini he:mek sa ko faloco'.
english: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

ami: Adihayay ko nisasingan no mako, sapipanengneng ci amaan ato ci inaan.
english: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

ami: Cila to a romi'ad hacafayen to no mako ci ama ato ci ina a tayra.
english: Next time I will come with my parents.

ami: Tona pa'aliwacan, tayra i Posong kako ato kaka to fafahiyan a miliso' ci fakian.
english: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.

ami: Nai Taypak kami mikalic to si'acefelay a tayra i Posong.
english: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

ami: Tahira i Posong, parakatay ci faki to paliding a militemoh tamiyanan.
english: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

ami: Cowa karaay ko loma' ni faki to siyataw, ano pakapaliding soni tahiraay to.
english: The station is not far from my uncle’s house, and it’s just a short drive away.

ami: Ira ko ta'angayay a pahotingan i ngata no loma' ni faki, mahakelong kami a citingsa tayra i pahotingan.
english: There is a big ranch near my uncle’s house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

ami: I pahotingan, keriden ni faki kami pariri' to siri ato mikalic to efa.
english: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

ami: Dadaya, mahakelong kami tayra i maci a malafi.
english: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

ami: Adihayay ko paliding i maci, mansa pakaotopay kami a tayra.
english: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

ami: Ya mamiliyas i, faheka matakaway ko otopay, saka mikalic to paso kami.
english: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

ami: Minokayay to kami tayra i Taypak no hatini, maxeraay hakiya ko otopay ni faki!
english: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don’t know if my uncle’s motorcycle has been found.

ami: Kaemang ho kako i, itiraay i Farangaw ko loma' niyam, mitilid to i, malinahay tayra i Taypak, itira sanay to ko 'orip i tokay.
english: When we were young, our family lived in Farangaw. After I started school, we moved to Taipei and have been living in the city ever since.

ami: Mitilid to i Tayhak, minanam kako to serangawan no Yincomin, cipinangay to a mafana' to makahirahiraay a serangawan no Yincominco i Taywan.
english: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

ami: Saka, anini mihecaan o pahanhanan to no kafaedetan i, minokay tayra i niyaro' mihomong to malitengay kako ato kaka to fa'inayan, hay mafana' to serangawan no niyah to a finacadan.
english: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

ami: Falo polo' to ko mihecaan noya malitengay, nika nengneng han hato tahatenokay ho ko mihecaan nira.
english: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

ami: Licay han no mako cingra o no icowacowaay ko kafana'an iso a sowal, seday sa ko sowal iso to no 'Amis, mafana' haca somowal to sowal no Ponong, Ngayngay ato Dipong.
english: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Pangcah, as well as Bunun, Hakka and Japanese.

ami: Nalicayen fana' sato kako, nano kaemangan cingra minanam to sowal no Dipong, o Ponong ko fafahi, i katayalan nira 'aloman ko kananaman a Ngayngay, mansa kahirahira sa ko kafana'an nira to sowal.
english: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is a Bunun, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

ami: Ya mihomong kami i, adihay ko nisowalan noya malitengay to pakayniay i taneng no litengan a likakawa no mi'adopay.
english: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

ami: Ano awa awa ko kafana'an niyam mitengil i, kaorira, loingen niyam i hawikidan a tingwa nga, nga'ay kami miliyaw a mitengil.
english: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

ami: Awaay ko kafanafana'an no mako to niyah to a finacadan ato serangawan, pakayni to nika o Yincomin ko tireng, ngodo sa kako.
english: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

ami: Matongal a matongal to ko fana' i, mahemeken to tona o 'Amis ko tireng, o siromaay, o tadakairayan.
english: The more I know, the more I feel that being a ’Amis is unique and something to be proud of.

ami: Ano pisakalafian i, o maminokay to ko safa to fa'inayan.
english: My younger brother is going home this evening.

ami: Tayra i cifa kako aci fofo mi'aca to koko', misaday to sakalafi no safa to fa'inayan.
english: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

ami: Mita'elif kami to pi'acaan to dateng, adihay ko kangdaway a dateng toya pi'acaan.
english: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

ami: Mi'aca kami to incay, koreto ato saytaw.
english: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

ami: Oya katihiay o paliwalay to losay a tawki, sowal sa, "koesanay ko onglay ato lopas ako. Mi'aca to miming makena!" saan.
english: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

ami: Mi'aca to kami to onglay ato lopas.
Mita'elif to kami toya paliwalay to koko', sowal sa koya tawki, "O maan ko 'a'acaen iso? Ta'angayay a masoesoay ko koko' anini, tolo so'ot ko cecay a koko'."
english: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

ami: 'Atekaken ci fofo, sakaemeden ko 'aca mamaanay han nira ko tawki a milicay.
english: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

ami: Kaemeday to ko 'aca saan ko sowal no tawki, cowa to kanga'ay a lowanen.
english: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

ami: Oya fiyaw i katihi a tawki sowal sa, katayni mi'aca to foting ako, kaemeday a ta'angayay ko foting ako saan.
english: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

ami: Ikor to, o koko' o foting ko ma'acaay niyam, tahaloma' mitangtang tomes sa ko dateng i cokowi.
english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

ami: Halafinay ko pitatala, to'eman to ko romi'ad.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

ami: Ira to ko tingwa no safa to fa'inayan, sowal sa, safana' sanay ko sowal no sofitay, cowa kanga'ay a pahanhan sa, liyaw no pa'aliwacan nga, nga'ayay pahanhan a minokay.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

ami: Adihay ko mitangtangan, pohayen ko salawinawina malacafay a komaen, sa ci fofo!
english: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

ami: Tahidangen to niyam ko salawinawina ato widawidang, malacafay a komaen tona sakadofah sanay a sakalafi.
english: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

ami: Ira ko cecay a widang ako ci Kacaw, halitawal cira to losid.
english: I have a classmate named Kacaw, he often forgets to bring things.

ami: Mitilid i, caliwen nira ko impic, sasipasip anca o ciwming no kapot.
english: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

ami: Kinacecay, kinatosa, kinatolo, maolah ho pacaliw ko kapot.
english: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

ami: Nikaorira, ira ko tatiihay a pinangan nira, marariday micaliw i, ca sa patikol.
english: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

ami: Ikor to i, mapili' to ko kapot a pacaliw ciraan to losid.
english: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

ami: Yo cecay a romi'ad, misalama kami talapapotal.
english: One day, we all went on an outing together.

ami: I fatad no lalan, sakatoma'iaw ci Kacaw, matawal nira miala ko silikami.
english: On the way, Kacaw wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

ami: Caliwen nira ko silikami no kapot, cowa kaala ako ko silikami han no kapot a pacako.
english: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn't bring them either.

ami: Tangil sa to ci Kacaw a marawraw. Keter sa cira, mana ca pacaliwen namo kako to silikami hani?
english: Kacaw burst into tears. He said angrily, why don't everyone lend me toilet paper!

ami: Sowal han no kapot, ca piala kiso to aalaen, ano pacaliwen ho kiso to losid i, cowa patikol.
english: The classmate told him, because you didn't bring it yourself, and you wouldn't return the things lent to you!

ami: To cila to a mitilid, Pacelem ci Kacaw tahira i kongkoan, Patikolen to ni Kacaw ko kapot to nicaliwan a losid.
english: The next day at school, Kacaw arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

ami: Mararaway kako han ni Kacaw ko kapot. Cowa to mamatawal ako ko losid a miala. Roma sa to, miahowiday kako to kapot to pipacaliw to losid.
english: kacaw apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

ami: O mi'adopay ko wama ako i niyaro'.
english: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

ami: Yo kaemang ho kako, dadaya mahadakay ca ama ato faki, o fonos ato kowang ko nihawikidan naira.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

ami: Tadengal to ko romi'ad i, hawikiden to naira ko tama' a minokay.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

ami: Anca o fafoy, anca o lawal, latek iraay ko tolok.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

ami: Sakilacen nangara ko tama' i sacomodan no niyaro'. Palilamen nangara ko finawlan.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

ami: Miaocil kako ci amaan, mitoor ci amaan a mi'adop.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

ami: Ta'angay to kako nga, hakelongen nira kako a mi'adop, san ci ama.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

ami: Mafana'ay ko fa'inayan no niyaro' a patalakal, misanga' cangra to wa'il a sapitalakal, ato sa'enec a sapitalakal.
english: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

ami: Mafana'ay misanga' ko wama a to wa'il a sapitalakal. Sowal sa ko wama, o sapitalakal to tolok koni sa. Songila'en a mitapal ko naripa'an no 'a'adopen, patelien i lalan no 'a'adopen.
english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

ami: Sapitooraw to malitengay a mi'adop, misaromi'ami'ad kako a minanam misanga' to sapitalakal. Nga, kaliki matalakal ko 'a'adopen.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

ami: Ma'araw no wama i, o aidahi kiso a mi'adop ano ta'angay to, han nira kako.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

ami: Ta'angayay to kako no hatini. Ca'elayen ako ko sapana' ato pana' ako, mahakelong to wama a mi'adop.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

ami: Minokay tahira i niyaro' i, palilamen ko finawlan to tama'.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

ami: Sowal sa ko wama, o aahowiden ita ko pipalemed no liteng to sakaadihay no tama' ita.
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.
I was late for school this morning.

ami: Ya malingad i, matawalay ako ko kafang.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

ami: Awa ko cecacecay a mihawikidan ako.
english: I didn't bring anything with me.

ami: Yo mipakafana' ko singsi i, hacafay hananay ako ko kapot a minengneng to tilid nira.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

ami: Yo miseking i, pacaliwan no kapot kako to impic ato sasipasip.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

ami: "Manikar a lomowad, aka to kaosoy!" han no singsi kako.
english: The teacher told me, Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!""
My good friend's name is Kacaw, and he is also an Amis child.

ami: Itira i Matang kami a mitilid.
english: We study together in the Tafalong tribe.

ami: Marariday kami a malacafay a mitengil to pipakongko no malitengay, Mafana'ay kami a misano'Amis.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Amis proficiently.

ami: 'Kawangay a maso^soay kako, Amerekay a mangiliway ci Kacaw.
english: I am tall and overweight, while Kacaw is short and thin.

ami: Si'icelay ci Kacaw. O kaolahan no nimanima cira.
english: Kacaw is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

ami: O piontokayan no kongkoan anini, adihayay ko misadayan no kongkoan to sakalalifet.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

ami: Malatengteng, mitenok to mali, comikay, makero ato mipana'.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

ami: Toya comikay kako i, matoro'ay kako, powak sanay ko 'ilang nanitoros.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

ami: Kaorira, lomowad kako, miliyaw ho a comikay.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

ami: Tahira kako i paherekan i, mahemak ko tamdaw a maemin.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

ami: Ano cowa kaalaala ko sakacecay a ngangan i, kaorira, mahemekay kako. Nawhan i, malaheciay ako ko kalalifet.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

ami: Nacila, miliso'ay kako ato ama ako to faki ako.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

ami: Pasowalen nira kami, maofangay ko fadahong no loma'.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

ami: Yo misanga' cira to fadahong i, matefaday nanifadahong.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

ami: Paterongen no ama ci faki to titi no kolong ato 'icep.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

ami: Malaholoholol kako ato faki i kafoti'an, adihay ko mipainian nira a kongko.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

ami: Yo mamiliyas kako i, 'akawangay to kako, sanengseng haca saan ci faki,
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

ami: Pacako han ako, "Ano ma'adah to ko oo' no faki i, katayhi ho i loma' niyam a misalama."
english: I said, When your foot gets better

ami: I tosa lefot tosa polo' ira ko tosa a mihecaan, midemak ko seyfo to kayki o nga'ayay to a pakafiten ko ngangan no Yencomin i nifonsiw.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

ami: Mihomong kako ci Fadasan o milongcay to sefo to pipakafit to ngangan no Yencomini i nifonsiw a kapah no niyaro' cira.
english: I interviewed Fadas, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

ami: Matatelek to kako ato mira tona pa'aliwan a mihomong ciraan.
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

ami: Toya pihomongan i, siwkayen nira kako to sakaira no ngangan nira, mipakafana' haca to laloma'an nira, niyaro' nira.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

ami: Licayen ako cira, mana pacici sa cira a mifalic to ngangan, ya matelangay a mitingkian a ngangan, cowa kanga'ay haw?
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

ami: Sowal han nira kako, cowa kamoecel ko tilid no Kowaping to todong no ngangan nira. Anca i, "Fa syen sen" hananay no tao cira, saka adihay ko kalatawaan nona pipangiha' to ngangan.
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Fa Xian Sheng

ami: Sowal sa ci Fadas, "O no Yencomin ko mitilidan a ngangan nga, o tadangangan no mita. O sakatatodong no finacadan ita, laloma'an ita, tireng ita ko ngangan ako. Saka, nanay 'aloman ko patikolay to niyah to a ngangan."
english: Fadas said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

ami: Nacila malacafay kako ato fofo tayra i cifa a paliwal. Adihay ko mialaan ni fofo to mipalomaan nira a dateng, halo mitangtangan nira a kakaenen.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

ami: Maolahay cangra to nipaliwalan no fofo a dateng. 'Alomanay ko mi'acaay to 'adiyamay ato tayaling. 'Aloman ko komaenay to mitangtangan nira a dateng.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

ami: Ya mitangtangan nira a paheko ato hakhak i, 'adetay. Ira ho ko misakohawan a titi no fafoy, masolot no fangsis nira ko lafang. Alaraoraod sa a misarayaray mi'aca.
english: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

ami: Ya mitantang ko fofo i, mitahidang kako to tamdaw. Miowing kako, "Saheto o mipalomaan no fofo ako kona dateng, cowa kapaiyoen, halikien a mi'aca!"
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

ami: Kaliki a mapaliwal ko dateng niyam. Sowal sa ko fofo, "Iraay kiso a mipadang kira."
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, \It’s all thanks to your help.\""

ami: Pakayni tona demak, mafana' to kako to dateng no Yencomin ato kalofana' no kakaenen, matinako haca ko roray no mipaliwalay.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

ami: Ma'araw ko nikaolah no fofo to no litengan a dateng, tada mairay ato malemed kako.
english: Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

ami: Pito ko toki tahiraay to ikongkoan kako anini.
english: I arrived at school at seven today.

ami: Misatapng to minanam, micomoday to ko singsi, sowalsa ko hanciw; katomireng! mita'ong!
english: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

ami: Sata'angay hahanay niyam ko ngiha nga'ay ho singsi.""
Minanam i, pakafana'en no singsi kita to sa'osi no 'Amis.
english: In class, the teacher taught us the ’Amis language of numbers.

ami: toolen niyam ko singsi misa'osi, romadiw kami to sa'osi a radiw.
english: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

ami: Adihayay ko ninanaman no mako a sowal to no 'Amis.
Malingad kako to romi'ami'ad a mitilid, minanam kako to romi'ami'ad to sowal no 'Amis, o papatengilen ko wina to pisano 'Amis ako.
english: I go to school every day, I learn the ’Amis language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

ami: CiPiya' ko ngangan no wama ako.
CiHongay ko ngangan no wina ako.
Ira ko cecay a kaka ako to fa'inayan, ciKolas ko ngangan nira moetep ira ko cecay ko mihecaan nira.
english: I have a brother, his name is kolas, he is 11 years old.

ami: Mahecad ko pitilidan niyam a kongkoan.
english: We study in the same school.

ami: Maolah romadiw' kako ato kaka to fa'inayan.
english: Both my brother and I like to sing.

ami: Maolah midangoy kako, pahanhan to i, malacafay midangoy ko paro no loma' niyam.
english: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

ami: Molah misafaeloh a ciwidang kako, malacafay romadiw ato midangoy kami.
english: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

ami: Lalima ko tamdaw no loma' niyam.
english: There are five people in our family.
There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

ami: Malacafay ko aro' ako ato wama, wina, kaka to fa'inayan ato kaka to fafahiyan.
english: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

ami: 'Akawangay ko wama ako, o Imeng cingra.
english: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

ami: Mangiliway ko wina ako, o ising cingra.
english: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

ami: I loma' ko wama ako misano 'Amis a caciyaw tamiyanan.
english: My father speaks the ’Amis language with us at home.

ami: O kafaedetan a pahanhanan minokayay tayra i niyaro' kami.
english: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

ami: Malacafayay kami a tatolo mitepa' to takola'.
english: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

ami: Maolahay kako to paro no loma' niyam.
english: I like our family very much.

ami: Malacafay kako ato Ina misalama anini.
english: I went out with my mother today.

ami: Salangdaw sanay ko kakarayan to romi'ad, cowa ka sienaw anca cowa kafaedet ko romi'ad, saemer ko fali.
english: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

ami: I rengorengosan komaen to miyen-paw kami tadadiheko a mapacidal ko tireng.
english: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.

ami: Helek no lahok, mafalic to a kahengang ko kakarayan.
english: In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

ami: Licay han no mako ciIna, mana kahengang ko kakarayan.
english: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

ami: Sowal sa ciIna, wa ira ko faliyos tayni alatek.
english: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

ami: O kakarayan to dadaya awaay ko 'o'ol, cowa kahadak ko fo'is.
english: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

ami: Toya pinokayan a lalan, mitolon kako to fo'is.
english: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

ami: Nanay awa a tayni ko faliyos, manga'ay a mahadak misalam kako.
english: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

ami: Itatihiay no kongkoan ko loma' ako, rakat sanay kako to romi'ami'ad, rakat sanay a minokay.
english: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

ami: Cowa kata'angay ko kongkoan niyam, cakahakowa ko mitiliday, mafana' a madadama kami.
english: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

ami: Masa'op i ontofa ko kaemangay, malacafay a mimali, malacafay a mahaholol.
english: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

ami: Kami ato singsi malacafay a misalama, o kongkoan mahecad to laloma'an niyam.
english: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

ami: Romi'ami'ad miasik kami, o rawang ma'olacay no polong a miasik.
english: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

ami: Roma tamdaw misisit to tanameng roma tamadaw miasik.
english: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

ami: Miasik haca kami to kalotadimocokan no kongkoan, makomod ko polong to tatayalen, masolinga' a ma'olac ko kongkoan.
english: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

ami: Inacila, tayra kako iniyaro' miliso' ciakongan.
english: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

ami: Halafin to caka saso'araw kami, ma'ilol to kako cingraan.
english: We haven't seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

ami: Ma'araw ni akong kako, pakaen takowanan to kacawas, pananomen ho kako to ociya.
english: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

ami: O nipalomaan niakong a kacawas koesanay.
english: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

ami: Maolaha kako to ociya niakong, nga'ayay nanomen.
english: I also like grandpa's tea, it's tasted good too.

ami: To kalahokan to i, malacafay kako cifofoan a mitangtang to salahok.
english: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

ami: Kadofah ko nitangtangan nifofo a salahok, ira ko foting, koko', ciyak, ato comoli.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

ami: Mahalek malahok, tayra kami i padatengan midateng.
english: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

ami: Adihay ko nialaan nifofo a konga, pafeli takowanan to tali ato lokyok, hawikiden no mako a panokay.
english: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

ami: O maminokay to kami, liyaw a romi'ad tayra sato miliso' cangraan.
english: I said goodbye to them and said I'd see them next time.

ami: Keliden no singsi kami tayra i pinanowangan, misarayaray i ka'ayaw no fawahan to mami'aca kami to paya.
english: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

ami: Micomod i pinanowangan i, sowal sa ko singsi; ora ika'ayaway i. o 'aya'ayaman
Matalaway kako to 'oner, mansa cowa pinengneng kako to 'one'onelan.
english: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

ami: Adihay ko 'ayam to ma'araway no mako, ira i kilang cangra a miaefer, ma'araw haca ko ekong i ofang no kilang a mafoti'.
english: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

ami: I pinanowangan ira ko eco, efa ato lokedaw, i tiya ho cowa paka'araw kako to pinanowang, ma:hemek paka'araw anini.
english: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

ami: Adihayay ko misasingan no mako, sapipanengneng ciamaan ato ciinaan.
english: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

ami: Liyaw to a romi'ad toolen no mako ciama ato ciina malacafay a tayra.
english: Next time I will come with my parents.

ami: Tona pahanhanan, tayra i Posong miliso' cifakian kako ato kaka to fafahiyan.
english: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.

ami: Nai Taypak mikalic to kasoling a tayra i Posong kami.
english: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

ami: Tahira i Posong, parakatay cifaki to paliding a militemoh tamiyanan.
english: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

ami: I ngataay no ciyataw ko loma' nifaki, parakat to paliding caho caho tahira to.
english: The station is not far from my uncle's house, and it's just a short drive away.

ami: Ira ko ta'angayay a pipakaenan i ngata no loma' nifaki, citingsa kami matatoor tayra i pipakaenan.
english: There is a big ranch near my uncle's house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

ami: I pipakaenan, keriden nifaki pariri' to siri ato mikalic to efa kami.
english: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

ami: Dadaya, malahakelong tayra i maci a malafi kami.
english: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

ami: Adihayay ko paliding i maci, mansa pakaotopay tayra kami.
english: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

ami: Ya mamiliyas i, faheka matakaway ko otopay, saka mikalic to paso kami.
english: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

ami: Minokay to kami tayra i Taypak, haiken maxeraay to nifaki koya matakaway a otopay hakiya!
english: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don't know if my uncle's motorcycle has been found.

ami: I sikano ko loma' niyam, i kaemang ho, namitilid to, palinah tayra i takaw, itira sato ko 'orip i tokay.
english: When we were young, our family lived in sikano. After I started school, we moved to Kaohsiung and have been living in the city ever since.

ami: Na mitilid to iTasiye, patodong sanay kako a minanam to pakayniay i serangawan no Yin-co-min, cipinangay to a mafana' to makahirahiraay a serangawn no Yin-co-min-co i Taywan.
english: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

ami: Saka, anini mihecaan o pahanhanan to no kafaedetan i, minokay tayra i niyaro' miliso' to malitengay kako ato kaka to fa'inayan, hay mafana' to niyah a finacadana ato serangawan.
english: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

ami: Falo polo' to ko mihecaan noya malitengay, kawrira, nengneng han mato tahatenokay ho ko mihecaan nira.
english: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

ami: Licay han no mako cingra ono icowacowaay ko kafana'an iso a sowal, calicpic ko sowal nira to no 'Amis, mafana' haca to sowal no Ponong, Ngayngay ato no Dipong a sowal.
english: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in ’Amis, as well as Bunun, Hakka and Japanese.

ami: Nalicayen fana' sato kako, hanaw o nano kaemangan ho cingra minanamay to sowal no Dipong, o Ponong ko fafahi, i katayalan nira adihay ko kananaman a Ngayngay, mansa kahirahira ko kafana'an nira to sowal.
english: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Bunun, and he knows many Hakkas at work, so he can speak so many languages.

ami: Ya milicay kami i, sowal sa to maamaan to pakayniay mi'adopay a pinangan no litengan ato taneng.
english: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

ami: Ano awa awa ko kafana'an niyam mitengil i, kawrira, o tingwa ko sapiloing niyam, ta nga'ay kami miliyaw a mitengil.
english: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

ami: Awaay ko kafanafana'an no mako to niyah a serangawn ato finacadan, pakayni takowanan mangodo kako a miharateng.
english: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

ami: Matongalmatongal to ko fana' i, na o 'Aims ko tireng, o tadamasaromaay to, o kanono'an to a malita'ang.
english: The more I know, the more I feel that being a ’Aims is unique and something to be proud of.

ami: I kalafian anini, o maminokay ko safa to fa'inayan.
english: My younger brother is going home this evening.

ami: Tayra i icifa mi'aca to koko' ci fofo ato kako, misaday to sakalafi no safa to fa'inayan.
english: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

ami: Mita'elif kami to pi'acaan to dateng, adihay ko faelohay a dateng noya pa'aca'ay.
english: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

ami: Mi'aca to kami to incay, koreto ato saytaw.
english: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

ami: Oya pi'acaan to losay a tawki sowal sa, "koesanay ko onglay ato lopas ako, mi'aca to miming makenaay saw!"
english: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

ami: Mi'aca to kami itiya to onglay ato lopas.
Mita'elif to kami toya pi'acaan to koko', sowal sa koya tawki, "O maan ko 'a'acaen iso? ta'angay a masoeso ko koko' anini, tolo so'ot ko cecay a kakoko'an."
english: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

ami: 'Atekaken cifofo, sakaemeden ko 'aca mamanay han nira ko tawki a milicay.
english: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

ami: O sakaemeday to ko 'aca saan ko sowal no tawki, cowa to ko nganga'ay a lowanen.
english: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

ami: Oya tatihiay a tawki sowal sa, katayni mi'aca to foting ako, kaemeday a ta'angay ko foting no mako.
english: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

ami: Ikol to, o koko' o foting ko ma'acaay niyam, tahaloma' tangtangen tomes sa ko dateng i eto.
english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

ami: Halafin to ko pitatala, to'eman sato ko romi'ad.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

ami: Toya pitatalaan, ira ko tingwa no safa to fa'inayan sowal sa, malipalaw ira ko latoh no kalasofitayan, cowa kanga'ay pasera' ko sofitay sa. Liyaw hanto no pa'aliwacan a minokay.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

ami: Sowal sa ci fofo adihay ko mitangtangan pohayen ko salawinawina malacafay a komaen!
english: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

ami: Tahidangen to niyam ko salawinawina ato widawidang, malacafay a komaen tona sakadofah sanay a sakalafi.
english: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

ami: Ira ko cecay a kapot ako, ci Kacaw ko ngangan nira.
english: I have a classmate named Kacaw, he often forgets to bring things.

ami: Ano mitilid i, micaliw cingra to impic no kapot, sasipasip ato pitilidan.
english: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

ami: Kinacecay, kinatosa, kinatolo, pacaliwan no polong to manmaan cingra
english: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

ami: Kawrira manamnam to ko pinangan nira i, cowa to patikol to nicaliwan a manmaan.
english: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

ami: Ikol to, awaay to ko makahiay pacaliwa to manmaan cingraan.
english: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

ami: Ira ko cecay a romi'ad, mapolong kami tayra i pala misalama.
english: One day, we all went on an outing together.

ami: Ifatad no lalan, tatayra i tata'ian ci Kacaw, kawra matawal ningra ko silikami.
english: On the way, Kacaw wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

ami: Micalw to silikami no kapot cingra kawrira paca'of han no polong cingra, away ko mahawikiday no mako yo.
english: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn't bring them either.

ami: Tomangic ci Kacaw to rawraw aca, keter sa a somowal, mana capacaliwen namo kako to silikami!
english: Kacaw burst into tears. He said angrily, why don't everyone lend me toilet paper!

ami: Sowal han no kapot cingra, nawhani nacowa pihawikid kiso, roma sato pacaliwen kiso to manmaan, cowa patikol!
english: The classmate told him, because you didn't bring it yourself, and you wouldn't return the things lent to you!

ami: Tocila a romi'ad malingad mitilid, pacerem ciKacaw tayra i kongkoan, oya nicaliwan niKacaw a manmaan no kapot patikolen to nira ko kapot.
english: The next day at school, Kacaw arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

ami: Kangodoan to kamo han ni Kacaw ko kapot, ikol to mihawikid to kako to manmaan sa, ahowiday kapot i'ayaw nipacaliw kamo takowanan to manmaan makahi kako a pacaliw tamowanan.
english: kacaw apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

ami: O mi'adopay a tamdaw i niyaro' ko wama ako.
english: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

ami: I kaemang ho kako, o dadaya ho mahadak to ci ama ato ci faki, mihawikid to fonos ato kowang.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

ami: Tadengal ko romi'ad, hawikiden to nangra a panokay ko tama'.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

ami: Latek o fafoy, anca o lawal, roma i, latek iraay ko torok.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

ami: I sacomod no niyaro' malalilam cangra to tama' a pafatis to finawlan.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

ami: Liyangen to ako ci ama to romi'ami'ad, to sapi'ociraw aca ciamaan a mi'adop.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

ami: Sowal sa ci ama, ta'angay to kako nga' itiya sato mikelid cingra takowanan a malingad.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

ami: O talakal ko sapilamec to tama' ko fa'inayan no niyaro', misanga' cangra to wa'il a talakal ato fakeloh a talakal.
english: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

ami: Mafana'ay a misanga' to wa'il a talakal ci ama ako, sowal sa ci ama, "o sapitalakal to torok koni, solinga'en no mita a minengneng ko narakatan a saripa' no 'a'adopen, itiraen ko talakal a miteli i karomakatan no 'a'adopen."
english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

ami: To romi'ami'ad a minanam kako misanga' to talakal, sakikahenay a mihakelong to malitengay a mi'adop, 'araw han kahenayay citama' koya talakal no mako.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

ami: Ma'araw niama ako sowal sa, "ikol to o tadamaanay to kiso a mi'adopay a tamdaw."
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

ami: Ta'angayay to kako no hatini, mikoyod kako to pana' ato 'idoc, mihakelong ciamaan a mi'adop.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

ami: Minokay to tahira i niyaro' i, pafatisen to ako ko fanawlan to tama' ako.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

ami: Sowal sa ci ama, "miahowiday kita to sapalemed no liteng, milongoc to sapakadofah no mita to tama'."
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.
I was late for school this morning.

ami: Tayra i pitakcian haw i, matawalay ako ko kacikafang.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

ami: Awaay ko maanmaan a mihawikidan ako.
english: I didn't bring anything with me.

ami: Minanam to i, malacecay minengneng to tilid kako ato kapot.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

ami: Misekin to i, pacaliwen no kapot kako to impic ato sasipasip.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

ami: Sowal sato ko singsi i takowanan "miliyaw to malatal a lomowad, aka to kaapac!"
english: The teacher told me, Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!""

ami: Ci Kacaw han ko sanga'ayay a widang ako, O wawa no 'Amis cingra.
english: My good friend's name is Kacaw, and he is also an Amis child.

ami: Malacafay kami a mitakeci i Fanaw a niyaro'.
english: We study together in the Tafalong tribe.

ami: Mararid kami malacafay mitengil to pakongko no malitengay, saheto mafana'ay kami a misano'Amsi.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Amis proficiently.

ami: 'Akawang a maso^:so kako, poener a mangiliw ci Kacaw.
english: I am tall and overweight, while Kacaw is short and thin.

ami: Tariktikay ci Kacaw, o kaolaolahan no 'alomanay cingra.
english: Kacaw is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

ami: O piontokayan no pitakcian anini, adihay ko lalifetan to mipatirengan no pitakcian.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

ami: Ira ko matatengteng to saso'ot, mitenok to mali, comikayay, misakeroay, mipana'ay.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

ami: Toya kacomikay ako haw i, mapolin kako, adihay ko 'ilang nai toros no mako.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

ami: Nikaorira lomowad kako, milingato a pasi'ayaw a comikay.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

ami: Tangasa to kako i pipatosokan mahemek ko 'alomanay.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

ami: Mahaenhaen caka pakaala to sakacecay, nikaorira mahemekay kako, Hay o malaheciay to ko lalalifeten ako.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

ami: I nacila, miliso'ay kako ato wama to faki ako.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

ami: Pasowal cingra i tamiyanan, maofangay ko fadahong no loma'.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

ami: Oya misanga' cingra to fadahong i, matefaday nanifadahong.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

ami: Paterongen no wama ci faki to titi no kolong ato 'icep.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

ami: Malalicalicay kako ato faki i kafoti'an i, adihay ko mipainian ningra a kongko.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

ami: Yo mamiliyas kako to 'ayaw i, mipahemek ko faki i takowanan to "'aka:wang to a tanes:tes to kiso" saan.
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

ami: Pacaof han ako, "Ano ma'adah to ko oo' no faki i, katay ho i loma' niyam a mihalama."
english: I said, When your foot gets better

ami: I tosa ca'ol tosa polo' ira ko tosa a mihecaan, mitahidang ko seyfo to pakayni i manga'ay deng ono finacadang a ngangan matilid i nifonsiw no Yencomin a kayki.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

ami: Mihomong kako to halafinay a milongc to seyfo to pipakafit to ngangan no Yencomin i nifonsiw a kapah no niyaro' ci Namoh Tongso'.
english: I interviewed Namoh Tongso’, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

ami: Matatelek kako ato cingra tona pa'aliwacan tayra i loma' ningra a mihomong cingranan.
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

ami: Toya pihomongan i, siwkayen ningra kako to sakaira no ngangan ningra, mipakafana' haca to laloma'an ningra, niyaro' ningra.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

ami: Licayen ako cingra, mana padeteng sa mifalic to ngangan, ya telang a mitingkian a ngangan, cowa kanga'ay haw?
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

ami: Sowal sa cingra i takowanan, cowa kamo^ecel ko tilid no Kowaping to todong no ngangan nira. Anca i, "Na-siyen-sen" hananay no tao cingra, saka, adihay ko sakatawaan nona ngangan.
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Na Xian Sheng

ami: Sowal sa ci Namoh, "O no Yencomin ko mitilidan a ngangan nga, o tadatatodongay a ngangan kitaanan. O sakatatodong no finacadan ita, laloma'an ita, tireng ita ko ngangan ako. Saka, nanay 'aloman ko mitikol to niyah a ngangan."
english: Namoh Tongso’ said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

ami: I nacila malacafay kako ato fofo tayra i icifa a paliwal. Adihay ko mi'olongan ni fofo to mipalomaan ningra a dateng, mitangtang haca cingra tono Yincominay a kakaenen to sapakaen to 'alomanay.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

ami: 'Alomanay ko maolahay to nipaliwalan ni fofo a dateng. 'Alomanay ko mi'acaay to kamamoday ato tayalin. 'Aloman ko komaenay to mitangtangan ningra a dateng.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother's stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

ami: Tadaka^so' koya nitangtangan ningra a paheko ato hakhak. Ira ho ko mitengelan to titi no fafoy a makaw-loro. Oya kafangsis mapasolot to ko 'alomanay. Taynitayni sato ko 'alomanay a misarayaray a mi'aca.
english: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

ami: Oya mitantang ho ko fofo i, miannay kako to lafang. Sata'angay sa ko pi'a'iyoy ako, "Saheto o no niyah a mipalomaan, cowa kapaiyoen, halikien a tayni mi'aca yo!"
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, The vegetables are self-grown

ami: Kalikiay a mapaliwal ko dateng niyam. Sowal sa ci fofo, "Hay, iraay kiso a mipacafay kira"
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, It's all thanks to your help.""

ami: Pakayni toni a demakan, mafana' to kako to pakayni i dateng no Yencomin ato kalofana' no kakaenen, matinako haca ko roray no mipaliwalay.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

ami: Ma'araw ko fofo to nikaolah tono litengan a dateng, Tada malita'ang ato maremed kako.
english: Seeing my grandmother's passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

ami: I Fata'an ko loma' no niyam.
Lalima^ ko paro^ no loma' niyam.
english: There are five people in our family.
There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

ami: Makomad kako a maro' aci mama^, ci ina^, ci kaka to fa'inayan ato kaka^ to fafahiyan.
english: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

ami: Takaraw ci mama^ ako; o tayring ci mama^ ako.
english: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

ami: Makopit ci ina^ ako; o ising ci ina^ ako.
english: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

ami: MisanoPangcah a somowal ci mama^ i tamiyanan i loma'.
english: My father speaks the Pangcah language with us at home.

ami: Minokay kami i niyaro' i pipahanhanan a romi'ad.
english: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

ami: Makomod kako aci kaka^ a milepel to takola^.
english: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

ami: Maolah kako to paro^ no loma' niyam.
english: I like our family very much.

ami: Ona pipahanhanan a romi'ad, talaPosong kako ato fafahiyan a kaka^ a miliso' ci fakian.
english: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.
We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

ami: Tangasa^ i Posong, pakapaliding ci faki^ a tayra i cya-taw militemoh i tamiyanan.
english: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

ami: Manga:ta^ to cya-taw ko loma' ni faki^, ano pakapaliding, colek sa tangasa^ to.
english: The station is not far from my uncle's house, and it's just a short drive away.

ami: Ira ko ta'akay a pipahotingan to kolong i ngata^ no loma' ni faki^, pakacitingsya^ kami a tayra toya pipahotingan.
english: There is a big ranch near my uncle's house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

ami: Itira toya pipahotingan, keriden ni faki^ kami a mipakaen to siri^ ato efa^.
english: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

ami: O dadaya^ sato, talapatiyamay kami a malafi^.
english: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

ami: Adihay ko paliding i patiyamay, saka pakaotofay kami a tayra.
english: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

ami: Tona taloma' to kami i, makoliniw ko otofay, saka pakafaso^ sato kami a taloma'.
english: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

ami: Anini^ tangasa^ to kami i Taypak, matepaay to koya otofay ni faki^ hakiya?
english: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don't know if my uncle's motorcycle has been found.

ami: I Fafokod ko loma' niyam yo mamang ho kako, micodad to kako i, malinah kami a tala-Taw-yin, itira: sato kami a ma'orip.
english: When we were young, our family lived in Fafokod. After I started school, we moved to Taoyuan and have been living in the city ever since.

ami: Micodad to i ta'akay picodadan i, minanam kako to cecay nananamen, pakayniay i serangawan no Yin-co-min, itira a mafana' to masamaamaanay a serangawan no Yin-co-min.
english: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

ami: Orasaka, aniniay pipahanhanan no picodadan, minokay a talaniyaro' kako aci kaka^ ako to fa'inayan, miliso' to mato'asay, mangalay a misapanang to serangawan no niyah.
english: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

ami: Falo^ to polo' ko mihecaan noya mato'asay, nika nengneng ri, tanektek ho^ ko tireng.
english: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

ami: Tengilen ako ciira, pina^ a sasowalan ko nikafana'an iso han ako, mafa:na' to no Pangcah a sowal ciira.
english: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in Pangcah.

ami: Mafana:' to no Tayan, no ngayngay ato no Ripon a sowal.
english: As well as Atayal, Hakka and Japanese.

ami: Na mitengilan to ako, saka mafana' kako, hilam o na micodaday ciira i kaRiponan yo mamang ho^.
english: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child.

ami: O Tayan ko fafahi^ nira, 'aloman ko kananaman nira a ngayngay i katayalan. Orasaka, adihay ko kafana'an nira a sowal.
english: His wife is an Atayal, and he knows many [Hakkas] at work, so he can speak so many languages.

ami: Yo mitengil kami i, adihay ko nipainian no mato'asay to pakayniay i fenek to pi'adop.
english: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

ami: Ano caaca:ay pakasapi:nang a mitengil i, nika ma-lo-ing niyam i saselican, manga'ay a tomadawen a mitengil.
english: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

ami: Yo mamang ho^ kako, caay ka fana' kako to serangawan no niyah, mangodo^ to ao Pangcah kako sa ko harateng.
english: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

ami: Matongal mato:ngal to ko nikafana' i, mahemek kako ao Pangcah ko tireng.
english: The more I know, the more I feel that being a Pangcah is unique and something to be proud of.

ami: I pitoay toki^ kako a talapicodadan anini^ a romi'ad.
english: I arrived at school at seven today.

ami: Misatapang to! Micomod to ko singsi^, sowal sato ko kakeridan, Kalomowad! Mita'ong!" saan."
english: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

ami: Sowal sa kami a mapo:long, "Nga'ay ho^ singisi^! saan."
Yo misatapang to kami a minanam i, pasifana'en no singsi^ kami to pisa'osi^.
english: In class, the teacher taught us the Pangcah language of numbers.

ami: Do^doen niyam ko piasip no singsi^, o sa'osi^ a sorit ko radiwen no niyam.
english: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

ami: Adihay ko ninanaman niyam a sowal no Pangcah.
english: I have learned many Pangcah languages.

ami: Talapicodadan kako to romi'ami'ad, mararid kako a minanam to sowal no Pangcah, patengilen ako ci ina^.
english: I go to school every day, I learn the Pangcah language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

ami: Ci Kacaw ko ngangan no mako.
Ci Asing ko ngangan no mama^ no mako.
Ci Panay ko ngangan ni ina^ no mako.
Mo^tep to ko mihecaan no mako anini^ a mihecaan.
Ira ko kaka^ ako to fa'inayan, ci Kolas han ciira, safaw cecay to ko mihecaan niira.
english: I have a brother, his name is kolas, he is 11 years old.

ami: O malecaday ko picodadan no niyam.
english: We study in the same school.

ami: Maolah kako aci kaka^ ako a romadiw.
english: Both my brother and I like to sing.

ami: Maolah kako a midangoy. I pipahanhanan a romi'ad, makomod ko paro^ no loma' niyam a midangoy.
english: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

ami: Maolah kako a misaidang i cimacimaan, manga'ay kami a makomod a romadiw ato midangoy.
english: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

ami: Miholol kako aci ina^ no mako.
english: I went out with my mother today.

ami: Salangdaw sa ko kakarayan; caay ka sienaw, caay ka faedet; sasaepi' sa ko fali^.
english: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

ami: I semosemotan kako a komaen to man-to^, mapacidal ko tatirengan, sadiheko^ saan.
english: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.

ami: I herek no lahok, sakahengang sato ko kakarayan.
english: In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

ami: Milicay kako i ci ina^, Enaw kahengan ko kakarayan?" han ako."
english: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

ami: Sowal sa ci ina^, Alatek ira ko faliyos." saan."
english: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

ami: Awaay ko cahid i dadaya^, masadakay ko fo'is.
english: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

ami: I fatad no lalan to sakataloma', mitolon kako pasyra i fo'is.
english: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

ami: Na:nay caay ka tayni ko faliyos, nawhani mangalay ho^ kako a miholol.
english: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

ami: I tatihi^ no loma' niyam ko picodadan ako, romakat kako a talapicodadan to romi'ami'ad; taloma' i, romaka:t kako.
english: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

ami: Caay ka tata'ak ko picodadan niyam; caay ka 'aloman ko micodaday, masasofana' kami a mapo:long.
english: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.
