ami: Itira i piondoan a masa'opo^ ko wawa^ a mapo:long, malakapot a mimali^ ato malalicalicay.
english: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

ami: Mikapot ko singsi^ i tamiyanan a misalama^, matiya o ta'akay a laloma'an ko picodadan.
english: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

ami: Miasik kami to romi'ami'ad, hadimelen niyam a miasik ko riwang.
english: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

ami: Ira ko misisitay to sasingaran, ira ko miasikay to papotal.
english: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

ami: Songila'en no niyam a miasik ko liklik no picodadan no niyam, madadamadama^ kami a mapo:long, saka tamelac sa ko picodadan niyam to romi'ami'ad.
english: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

ami: Inacila^, tayra kako i niyaro' a miliso' ci akongan.
english: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

ami: Halafin to kami a caay kasaso'araw, maoron kako i ciiraan.
english: We haven’t seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

ami: Ma'araw ni akong kako ri, pakaen ciira to sinar i takowanan, ato pa-ocya^ i takowanan.
english: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

ami: Macedem ko nipalomaan ni akong a sinar, kaeso'.
english: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

ami: Maola:h kako to o-cya^ ni akong, fangsis a nanomen.
english: I also like grandpa’s tea, it’s tasted good too.

ami: O kalahokan sato, makomod kako aci ama: a misakalahok.
english: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

ami: Adi:hay ko nisacacakan ni ama: to sinafel, ira ko foting, o 'ayam, o tamorak, ato ira haca^ ko kacomoli^.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

ami: Herek no lahok i, talapadatengan kami a midateng.
english: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

ami: Adihay ko nialaan ni ama: to fonga^, tali^, lokiyo^, pataloma'en sa i takowanan.
english: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

ami: "Taloma' to kako, tayni hato ako anoro:ma^ a romi'ad." han ako caira a palicay.
english: I said goodbye to them and said I’d see them next time.

ami: Keriden no singsi^ kami a tayra i tong-o-yin anini^ a romi'ad, masatisil kami a micakay to sapicomod a paya.
english: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

ami: Micomod to kami i tong-o-yin i, sowal sa ko singsi^, "I ka'ayaw i, ira ko 'aya'ayam; i kaikor i, ira ko 'one'oner, lonok han ita a minengneng." saan.
english: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

ami: Matalaw kako to 'oner, saka caay pinengneng kako to 'one'oner.
english: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

ami: Adihay ko manengnengay ako a 'ayam, misaefeefer caira i faled no kilang; ira a ma'araw ako ko ekong, mafoti' i laloma' no fohang no kilang.
english: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

ami: I laloma' no tong-o-yin, ira ko eco^, o efa^, o lokedaw; caay ho^ paka'araw kako i 'a:yaw, nika anini^ ma'araw to no mako, lipahak ko faloco'.
english: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

ami: Adihay ko nisya-si-ngan no mako, panengnengen no mako ci mama^ aci ina^.
english: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

ami: Anoro:ma a romi'ad, malahakelong kako aci mama^ aci ina^ a tayni.
english: Next time I will come with my parents.

ami: Anini^ a dadaya^, tataloma' to ko safa^.
english: My younger brother is going home this evening.

ami: Talapatiyamay kako aci ama: a micakay to 'ayam, sakalafi^ niyam ato safa^.
english: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

ami: Mita'elif kami to picakayan to sinafel, adihay ko faelohay a sinafel itira.
english: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

ami: Micakay kami to ing-cay, o koleto^ ato kahengayay a saytaw.
english: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

ami: Oya tatihiay, mipacakayay to heci^ no losay a tawki^, sowal sa: Macedem ko talacay ato lopas no mako
Micakay kami to talacay ato lopas.
Mita'elif kami to pacakayay to titi^ no 'ayam, sowal sa koya tawki^, "O maan ko cakayen iso? Fangcal maso^so^ kina 'ayam anini^, tolo^ li'an ko cecay." saan.
english: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

ami: Tada matekes sa ci ama:, saka licayen nira koya tawki^, "Sereren ko 'aca^ ari!" han nira.
english: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

ami: Ca'of sa koya tawki^, "Kaemeday to koni, caay to ka nga'ay sereren!" saan.
english: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

ami: Oya fiyaway a tawki^, sowal sa, "Ini ko foting ako, tata'ak ri kaemeday ko 'aca^." saan.
english: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

ami: Sarikoray sato, o 'ayam ato foting ko nicakayan no niyam, pataloma'en niyam a mitangtang.
english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

ami: Tatala: sa kami, to'eman to ko romi'ad.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

ami: Ira sato ko dingwa^ no safa^, sowal sa, "Awa^ aca^ ko pipahanhan no niyam o malahitayay, ro:ma^ to aca^ a lipay kako a taloma'." saan.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

ami: Sowal sato ci ama:, "Adihay ko nisacacakan ako. Ati! Malafi^ to kita !" saan.
english: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

ami: Takos hato no niyam ko malaynaay, mapo:long kami a malafi^.
english: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

ami: Ira ko tihi^ ako a micodad, ci Kacaw. Karapa:wan ciira to maamaan.
english: I have a classmate named Kacaw, he often forgets to bring things.

ami: Yo miteka^ to a micodad i, micaliw to sasorit, sasisit ato cacodadan no kapot.
english: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

ami: Kinacecay, kinatosa^, kinatolo^ i, pacaliwen ho^ no kapot ciira.
english: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

ami: Nika ira ko tatiihay a pinanang niira, tomatira caay panokas to nicaliwan.
english: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

ami: I ikor sato, caay to pacaliwen no kapot ciira.
english: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

ami: Cecay a romi'ad, talapapotal a miholol kami a mapo:long.
english: One day, we all went on an outing together.

ami: I fatad no lalan, talakamayi'an ci Kacaw, mapawan niira ko wey-seng-ce.
english: On the way, Kacaw wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

ami: Micaliw ciira to no kapot, nika ca'of han no kapot ciira, "Awaa:y ko no mako." han naira.
english: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn't bring them either.

ami: Sakatomangican sato ci Kacaw. Telii^ sa ciira a somowal, "Nawiro caay pacaliaw kamo to wey-seng-ce i takowanan?" saan.
english: Kacaw burst into tears. He said angrily, why don't everyone lend me toilet paper!

ami: Sowal hato no kapot ciira, "Ca:ay pihakiwid kiso to no miso, ro:ma^ i, caay haca^ pipanokas kiso to nicaliwan iso." han nira.
english: The classmate told him, because you didn't bring it yourself, and you wouldn't return the things lent to you!

ami: Cila^ sato, maratar ci Kacaw a talapicodadan, panokasen ni Kacaw ko nicaliwan niira to kapot a mapo:long.
english: The next day at school, Kacaw arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

ami: Sowal sa ciira, "Maanen aca^ haw! I ikor i, caay to pitawal kako ko no mako a maamaan, aray to pihayda namo a pacaliw i takowanan i hatiniay lafin." han niira.
english: kacaw apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

ami: O mi'adopay no niyaro' ci mama^ ako.
english: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

ami: Yo mamang ho^ kako, o dadaya^ ko sakalingad ni mama^ aci faki^, cifonos ato cikowang caira.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

ami: Yo taengal to ko romi'ad i, pataloma'en naira ko maalaay a 'a'adopen.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

ami: Tomatira, ira ko fafoy, o fohet ato tolok.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

ami: Itira i sacomod no niyaro' a miwasil caira, pafatis to i niyaro'ay.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

ami: Mararid kako a milongoc ci maman a mido^do^ i ciiraan a mi'adop.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

ami: Sowal sa ci mama^, "Ano mato'as to kiso i, hakelongen ako kiso." saan.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

ami: Mafana'ay ko kapah no niyaro' a pipatilo^ to 'a'adopen, mafana' caira a misanga' to sapitilo^ ato sapita'eref.
english: The men of the tribe also trap their prey, making lasso traps and rock traps.

ami: Mafana' ci mama^ ako a misanga' to tilo^, sowal sa ciira, "Inian i, o saki'ayam, nengnengen ko naripa'an no 'a'adopen, itira i narakatan no 'a'adopen a miteli^." saan.
english: My dad is very good at making lasso traps. Dad said that this is used to catch pheasants. We have to carefully observe the footprints of the prey, and the traps should be placed on the path of the prey.

ami: Mangalay a mihakelong to mato'asay a mi'adop, saka minanam kako a misanga' to tilo^ to romi'ami'ad, ta narikay kako a pakaala^ to 'a'adopen.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

ami: Paka'araw ci mama^ to demak ako i, sowal sa, "O cacitaneng kiso a mi'adop." saan.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

ami: Anini^ mato'as to kako, koyod sato kako to 'idoc ato pana', mihakelong ci mamaan a mi'adop.
english: Now that I have grown up, I carry my bow and arrows and go hunting with my father.

ami: Taloma' sato kami na mi'adop i, pafatis to tama' to i niyaro'ay.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

ami: Sowal sa ci mama^, "Arayen ita ko pipalemed no tato'asan, ta mararid a pakaala^ to tama' a mi'adop." saan.
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.
I needed to go to school.

ami: Maapac kako i dafang tayra i picodadan.
english: I was late for school this morning.

ami: Yo tayra kako i picodadan, matawal ako ko kafang.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.

ami: Awa ko nihawikidan ako a maamaan.
english: I didn't bring anything with me.

ami: Micodad sato, i kapot sato kako minengneng to codad.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

ami: pisekingan sato, pacaliw saan ko cafay to inpic ato sapisisit. i takonan.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

ami: pasowal sa ko singsi i takonan: "aka to paliyaw maapac, karatar molowad to dafak!"
english: The teacher told me, Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!""

ami: Ci Canglah ko ngangan no widang ako, sakalecadto o wawa no pangcah cingra.
english: My good friend’s name is Canglah, and he is also an Amis child.

ami: Malakapot kami i makotaay niyaro' micodad.
english: We study together in the Tafalong tribe.

ami: Hinatengilay kami malacafay to pakimad no matoasay, sakafana niyam somowal to soawl no pangcah.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Amis proficiently.

ami: Takarw masoso aca kako, paener makoli aca ci Canglah.
english: I am tall and overweight, while Canglah is short and thin.

ami: Tariktik saan ci Canglah, Kaolahan no 'alomanay cingra.
english: Canglah is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

ami: Piondoankayan no picodadan anini romi'ad, mipalowad ko picodadan to adihayay a salifet.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

ami: Ira ko masasolotay, saliwa'ay mimali, comikayay, masakeroay ato mipana'ay.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

ami: Oya kacomikay ako i, matolo'ay kako, ta:no remes sanay ko tosor ako.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

ami: Nikaorira lomowad kako, misingto tala'ayaw comikay.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

ami: Tangasa kako i paherekan i lipahak maemin ko mikiaraway.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

ami: Talacowa caay pakaala to sakacecay ngangan, nikaorira maolah kako, nawhani malaheci ako konini a lifet.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

ami: Miliso kako ato mama ci fakian ako i nacila.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

ami: Matepong ko fadahong no loma' saan cingra pasifana i tamiyanan.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

ami: Toya palolol ningra misanga' to fadahong i, matefaday makonkon.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

ami: Cihawikid to titi no kolong ato 'icep sapafeli ci fakian.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

ami: Malalicay kako ato faki i rawang, paini cingra to maamaanay a kimad.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

ami: Yo mamiliyas kako i, cina lahadan to kako saan cifaki mihemek, i takonan tanestes aca ko laleko saan.
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

ami: Pasowal hanako, "ano maadahto ko wa'ay ni faki, itiya haanto tayni i loma niyam misalama."
english: I said, When your foot gets better

ami: Makahi pacidek to ngangan no finacadan no Yin-Co-min i mifonsiw i saka tosa patek tosa polo ira ko tosa miheca palisafon ko Ceng-Fo milofang.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

ami: Liclicen ako to halafinay milongoc to Ceng-Fo a kapah no niyaro' to "sapicidek pangangan no finacadan" i mifonsiw.
english: I interviewed Noami Kulas, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

ami: Nikaherekan to ako patonek cingra tonini pa'aliwacan tayra i loma' ningra palafang.
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

ami: Yo piliclican i tiya i, pakafana' to naicowaay kolalengatan no ngangan ningra ato pasifana' to paro no loma' ato niyaro' ningra.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

ami: Nawiro no pacici nosa sapifalican to ngangan han ako milicay tatiih hakiya lecaden tono katelangay pangangan?
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

ami: Pasowl sa i takonan ciira ano pakiholamen a tilid ko ngangan ako i caay ka saheci ko pilikorar saan, saka hinapangangan sa to "Na singsi" ko roma tamdaw i cingraan, orasaka, malo tatawaen tonika haen.
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Na Xian Sheng

ami: Sowal sa ci Noami Kolas, "o tilid no Yin Co Min ko sapangangan a sorit ko matatodongay ngangan no mita. o sapawacay no finacadan, ngasaw ato tatirengan no mita, nanay 'aloma'aloman ko padotocay to ngangan no tato'asan."
english: Noami Kulas said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

ami: Mihakelong kako ci faian tayra i kalali'acaan, adihay ko nihawikidan to palomaan ni fai a dateng, ato nisanga'an tono Yin Co Min a kaeso'ay kakaenen sapalfeli to alomanay.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

ami: 'Aloman ko maolahay toya paliwalan ni fai, 'aloman ko miaca'ay to damdam ato kakorot, 'aloman ko mitanamay to ni safelan niira a dateng.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother’s stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

ami: Tada kaeso' ko nitangtangan niira a paheko ato hakhak, halo nipacamolan to makaw a nitengeran titi no lotok, misolot koya sanek to 'alomanay i lafang, maolah ko 'alomanay minaol to paliwalan niyam.
english: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

ami: Yo mi tangtang ci fai i, mihalhal kako to lafang, palalaha sa kako milekal i fati'i'an, "saheto ono niyah palomaan a dateng caay ko nipahiliwan kalamkam tayni miaca."
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, \The vegetables are self-grown

ami: Oya sapa'aca niyam i harakat sa maemin ma'aca, sowal sa ci fai, "o nika iraan iso mipadang ko sakahaen."
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, \It’s all thanks to your help.\""

ami: Onini sa'opo i ira ko pinanam ako to pinaloma no Yin Co Min ato kakaenen no taneng halo roray no paliwalay a citinako to.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

ami: Ma'araw no mako ko 'omi ni fai to mirocokan a kakaenen tada malemed ato malit'ang ko faloco' ako.
english: Seeing my grandmother’s passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

ami: pito ko toki tahiraay to kako i pitilidan anini.
english: I arrived at school at seven today.

ami: pisatapangan to a minanam, micomoday to ko singsi i laloma' no pitilidan, "katomireng, mita'ong" sa ko kakeridan.
english: It’s time for class , the teacher walked into the classroom, and the monitor said: “Stand up! Salute!”

ami: sata'angay sa ko ngiha niyam a pasowal to "nga'ay ho singsi."
to pinanaman i, pasifana'en no singsi kami to sa'osi no 'Amis.
english: In class, the teacher taught us the ’Amis language of numbers.

ami: todongan niyam ko pisa'osi no singsi, radiwan niyam ko sa'osi.
english: We followed the teacher to read, we sang the number song.

ami: adihay to ko kafana'an no mako to sowal no 'Amis.
mitilid kako to romi'ami'ad, minanam kako to sowal no 'Amis to romi'ami'ad, papitengilen ako ci ina to sowal ako.
english: I go to school every day, I learn the ’Amis language every day, and I want to tell my mother.

ami: ci Kacaw ko ngangan no mako.
ci Asing ko ngangan no wama ako.
ci Panay ko ngangan no wina ako.
mo^tepay to ko mihecaan no mako anini.
cecayay ko kaka ako, ci Kolas ko ngangan ningra, cecayay to ko safaw ko mihecaan ningra.
english: I have a brother, his name is kulas, he is 11 years old.

ami: malacecayay ko pitilidan niyam a mitilid.
english: We study in the same school.

ami: maolah kako aci kaka a romadiw.
english: Both my brother and I like to sing.

ami: maolah kako a midangoy, paaliwacan i, malahakelong ko paro no loma' niyam a midangoy.
english: I like swimming. During the holidays, our whole family go swimming together.

ami: maolah kako a misawidang to fa^lohay a widang, manga'ay kami a malacafay romadiw ato midangoy.
english: I love meeting new people, we can sing and swim together.

ami: lalima ko paro no loma' niyam.
english: There are five people in our family.
There are three brothers and sisters in our family.

ami: malacafay kako to wama, wina, kaka to fa'inayan ato kaka to fafahiyan a ma'orip.
english: I live with my father, mother, brother and sister.

ami: akawangay ko wama ako, o malatayxinay ko wama ako.
english: My father is tall and he is a policeman.

ami: mangiliway ko wina ako, o malaisingay ko wina ako.
english: My mother is thin and my mom is a doctor.

ami: sano'Amisan no wama kami a caciyaw i loma'.
english: My father speaks the ’Amis language with us at home.

ami: pa'aliwacan to kaciherangan i, minokay kami a talaniyaro'.
english: We will all go back to the tribe during the summer vacation.

ami: malacafay kako to kaka to fa'inayan fafahiyan a mitakora'.
english: My brothers and sisters and I will catch frogs together.

ami: maolah kako to paro no loma' niyam.
english: I like our family very much.

ami: masadakay kako aci ina a misalama anini.
english: I went out with my mother today.

ami: sa langdaw sa ko kakarayan to romo'ad, cowa kafa^det cowa kasi^naw, saemelay ko falifali.
english: The sky is blue during the day, the weather is neither cold nor hot, and the wind is cool.

ami: i rengorengosan kami a komaen to ^pang, mapaedil no cidal ko tatirengan, tada dihekoay.
english: We ate bread on the grass, the sun was shining on us, and it was very warm.

ami: herek no lahok, masakahengangay to ko kakarayan.
english: In the afternoon, the sky turned red.

ami: licay han ako ci ina, mana kahengang ko kakarayan.
english: I asked my mother why the sky is red.

ami: sowal sa ci ina, wa aira ko faliyos a tayni alatek.
english: Mom said, maybe the typhoon is coming.

ami: awaay ko to'em/kadit i kakarayan, masadakay to ko fo'is.
english: There were no clouds in the sky at night, and the stars came out.

ami: i fatad no pinokayan a lalan, ira ko pinanay no faloco' ako to fo'is.
english: On the way home, I made a wish with the stars,

ami: nanay aka ho katayni koni a faliyos, sakasadakan nanay ho kako a misalama.
english: I hope the typhoon doesn't come, I still want to go out to play again.

ami: i tatihiay no loma' ako ko pitilidan, saka rakat sanay kako a talapitilidan, rakat sanay kako a minokay to romi'ami'ad.
english: My school is next to our house, I walk to school every day, and I also walk home.

ami: cowa katata'ang ko pitilidan niyam, cowa ka'aloman ko mitiliday, sahto o kananaman to.
english: Our school is not big, there are not many students, everyone knows each other.

ami: cowa kata'angay ko pitilidan niyam, cowa ka'aloman ko mitiliday, sahto o kananaman to.
english: All the children will gather in the playground, play ball and chat together.

ami: mapolong ko kaemangay a masa'opo i kasa'opoan a malacecay ko pisalama kalalicay.
english: The teachers also play with us, the school is one big family.

ami: mikihatiyaay ko singsi i tamiyanan a misalama, o ta'angyay to a laloma'an ko pitilidan.
english: We have to clean every day, and everyone has to clean the classroom.

ami: miasikay to kami to romi'ami'ad, songila'en ita a miasik ko pitilidan.
english: Some people clean the windows, some sweep the floor.

ami: misifin ko roma to sasingaran, miasik ko roma to paenan.
english: We will also clean every corner of the school. Everyone works together, and the school is very clean every day.

ami: tayraay kako i niyaro' a miliso' ci akongan i nacila.
english: Yesterday, I went to visit my grandpa in the tribe.

ami: halafinay to a ca kasaso'araw kami, ma'ilolay to kako i cingranan.
english: We haven’t seen each other for a long time and I miss him a lot.

ami: paka'araw ci akong i takowanan, tangsol sa a pakaen i takowanan to kacawas, pananom to ociya i takowanan.
english: As soon as grandpa saw me, he invited me to eat watermelon and drink tea.

ami: ko^sanay ko nipalomaan ni akong a kacawasay, so^lin tada nga'ayay to a kaenen.
english: The watermelon grown by grandpa is very sweet and really delicious.

ami: maolahay kako to ociya ni akong, nga'ayay to a nanomen.
english: I also like grandpa’s tea, it’s tasted good too.

ami: kalahokan to i, malacafay kako aci mamoan a misakalahok.
english: At noon, I cooked lunch with my grandma.

ami: kadofah ko mitangtangan ni mamo a sakalahok, ira ko foting, koko', tamorak ira ho ko katacomoli.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

ami: kadofah ko mitangtangan ni mamo a sakalahok, ira ko foting, koko', ciyak ira ho ko cori'.
english: Grandma cooked a big lunch, including fish, chicken, pumpkin, and snails.

ami: maherek a malahok i, tayraay kami i padatengan a midateng.
english: After lunch, we went to the vegetable garden to pick vegetables.

ami: adihayay ko mipafelian ni mamo i takowanan to mialaan ningra a konga, tali ato rakiw to hapapanokayen no mako.
english: Grandma brought me a lot of sweet potatoes, taro and buckwheat, and asked me to take them home.

ami: arayom han to ako cangra a pasowal to miliyaw ho kako a tayni miliso' han ako.
english: I said goodbye to them and said I’d see them next time.

ami: keridan no singsi kami a tayra i pi'arawan to pinanowang, masarayaray kami i fawahan a mi'aca to paya.
english: Today the teacher took us to the zoo, and we lined up at the gate to buy tickets.

ami: micomod to kami i pinanowangan, sowal sa ko singsi, "o 'aya'ayaman ko i ka'ayaway, o 'oner'oneran ko kaikoray, pakoniyaniyah sa kita a mi'araw."
english: After entering the zoo, the teacher said, There are birds in the front and snakes in the back

ami: matalaway kako to 'oner, saka cowa kapi'araw kako to 'oner.
english: I'm afraid of snakes, so I don't look at snakes.

ami: ma'araw ako ko adihayay a 'ayam misaefeefer cangra i kilakilangan, ma'araw ho ako ko ekong a mafoti' i dihif.
english: I saw a lot of birds flying around in the trees and saw owls sleeping in tree hollows.

ami: ira aca ko eco, efa ato lokdaw i pinanowangan, sahto sa o cowa ho ka'araw ako i 'ayaw ho, salipahak sa kako a paka'araw anini.
english: There are elephants, horses and tigers in the zoo. I have never seen these animals before. I was really happy to see them today.

ami: adihayay ko nisasingan ako to hasapanengneng ci mamaan ci inaan.
english: I took a lot of pictures and showed them to my parents.

ami: miliyaw i, hacafayen ako ci mama ci ina a tayni.
english: Next time I will come with my parents.

ami: tona pa'aliwacan a romi'ad, tayraay kako ato kaka ako to fafahiyan i Posong a miliso' ci fakian.
english: This holiday, my sister and I went to Taitung to visit my uncle.

ami: nani Taypak kami a mikalic to cinamalay a tayra i Posong.
english: We took the train from Taipei to Taitung.

ami: tahira sa to i Posong, pakapaliding ci faki a militemoh i tamiyanan.
english: When we arrived in Taitung, my uncle drove to the station to pick us up.

ami: cowa karaay ko loma' ni faki to siyataw, cahocaho tahiraay to.
english: The station is not far from my uncle’s house, and it’s just a short drive away.

ami: iraay ko cecay ta'angayay a pala to pipakaenan to 'a'adopan i ngata no loma' ni faki, malacecay kami a mikoliciw a tayra.
english: There is a big ranch near my uncle’s house, and we rode bicycles to the ranch together.

ami: itira tora pipakaenan, keriden ni faki kami a mipakaen to siri a mikalic to efa.
english: In the ranch, my uncle took us to feed the sheep and ride horses.

ami: to dadaya to i, malacafay kami a tayra i maci a malafi.
english: In the evening, we went to the city to have dinner together.

ami: adihayay ko paliding i maci saka, pakaotopay sa kami a tayra.
english: There are a lot of cars in the city, so we go there by motorcycle.

ami: ya mamiliyas to kami i, matakaway ko otopay no niyam saka, pakapaso sa to kami a minokay.
english: When we were about to leave, we found that the motorcycle had been stolen, so we had to leave by bus.

ami: tahiniay to kami i Taypak anohatini, ya otopay ni faki i, maxeraay to hakiya!
english: Now that we are back in Taipei, I don’t know if my uncle’s motorcycle has been found.

ami: itiniay i Posong ko loma' niyam i kakaemangan ho, mitilid to haw i, mafolaway to a tayra i Taypak, aitira sanay to i tokay ko 'orip.
english: When we were young, our family lived in Posong. After I started school, we moved to Taipei and have been living in the city ever since.

ami: mitilid to i ta'angayay a pitilidan i, minanamay kako tono serangawan no Yincomin, mafana' to kako to kahirahira, kadofah no serangawan no Taywan.
english: After I went to college, I took a course on aboriginal culture and learned that the aboriginal people in Taiwan have various and rich cultures.

ami: saka, anini a mihecaan to pipa'aliwacan to kaciherangan, minokay kako ato kaka ako a tayra i niyaro' a milicay to malitengay/mato'asay to sakafana'aw to serangawan no niyah a finacadan.
english: So this summer, my brother and I went back to our tribe to visit the elderly, hoping to understand the culture of our own ethnic group.

ami: faloay to a polo' ko mihecaan nora mato'asay, nengneng han hato kaemangay ho.
english: The old man is already eighty years old, but he still looks like a middle-aged man.

ami: o manan manan a sowalan ko kafana'an iso a somowal han ako a milicay cingra, tanestesay ko sowal ningra tono 'Amis, mafana' aca a somowal tono Piyoma, payrang ato no Dipong.
english: I asked him which languages he knew, and he was fluent in ’Amis, as well as Pinuyumayan, Hokkien and Japanese.

ami: licay han ako cingra a mafana' kako, yo kaemang ho cingra i, minanamay to to sowal no Dipong, o Piyoma ko fafahi ningra, alomanay aca ko kananaman ningra a Payrang i katayalan saka, adihay ko kafana'an ningra a sowal.
english: I asked him to find out that he learned Japanese when he was a child, his wife is an Pinuyumayan, and he knows many Hokkien at work, so he can speak so many languages.

ami: itini to kalalicay niyam, adihay ko makitohay no mato'asay to pakiniay to fenek no mi'adopay.
english: During our interview, the old man talked about a lot of traditional knowledge about hunting.

ami: talacowa cowa katadafana' kami a mitengil nika, tanotingwaan no niyam a misasing nga', nga'ay ko pisaliyaliyaw no niyam a mitengil.
english: Although we could’t fully understand it, we could record it on our cell phones and listen to it more.

ami: cowa kafana' kako to serangawan no niyah i kakaemangan ho, pakini to no niyah o Yencomin a tireng i, mangodoay to ko harateng.
english: When I was young, I didn’t understand the culture of my ethnic group, and I was a little embarrassed that I was an aborigine.

ami: ikor to haw i, mafana' to kako to tireng no niyah o 'Amis, o tadamaanay o micidekay, o kalita'angan to konini!
english: The more I know, the more I feel that being a ’Amis is unique and something to be proud of.

ami: wa minokay to ko safa to fa'inayan anini to kakeremam.
english: My younger brother is going home this evening.

ami: tayra kako aci mamo i cifa a mi'aca to koko', misaday to 'aredetay a sakalafi to hano safa.
english: My grandma and I went to the market to buy chickens and prepared a delicious dinner for my younger brother.

ami: mata'elif niyam ko paliwalay to dateng, adihay ko ko^ngelay a dateng to papaliwalen no paliwalay.
english: We passed the vegetable stand, which had a lot of fresh green vegetables.

ami: o incay, korto ato ningcing ko mi'acaan niyam.
english: We bought water spinach, yams and carrots.

ami: sowal sa koya tatihiay a tawki toya paliwalay to losay, "ko^sanay ko talacay ato lopas no mako, 'acaen ko pinapina makena!"
english: The owner of the nearby fruit stand said: “My pineapples and peaches are very sweet. Buy some!”

ami: 'acaan to niyam ko talacay ato lopas.
mata'elif niyam ko paliwalay to titi, sowal sa koya tawki, "o manan ko 'a'acaen no miso? ta'angayay maso^so aca koni a koko' anini, tolo a so'ot ko 'aca no cecay."
english: We passed the meat stall, and the boss said, “What do you want to buy? Today’s chickens are big and fat, and one is 300 NTD.”

ami: 'atekakan nanay ci mamo, manga'ay a saka'emeden to mamang han nira koya tawki a milicay.
english: Grandma thought it was too expensive and asked the boss if it could be cheaper.

ami: nikawrira, ka'emeday to, caay to kanga'ay a lowanen sa ko sowal noya tawki.
english: But the boss said that it is already very cheap and cannot be reduced any further.

ami: pasowal sa koya tatihiay a tawki, "katayni a mi'aca to foting ako, ta'angayay ka'emeday aca ko foting ako."
english: The boss next door said, come and buy my fish, my fish is big and cheap.

ami: ikor to i, ma'aca to niyam ko koko' ato foting, minokay a tahaloma' i, tangsol sa a mitangtang to cecay a 'eto a kakaenen.
english: In the end we bought chicken and fish, and went home to cook a table of food.

ami: halafinay to ko pitatala, to'eman sa to ko romi'ad.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

ami: sa to'eman sa to ko romi'ad to pitatalaan.
english: After waiting for a long time, it was already dark.

ami: patingwa ko safa a pasowal, safana'sa a awa ko 'aliwac no sofitay sa, roma sa to a lipay to pa'aliwacan nga' manga'ay a minokay saan.
english: The younger brother called back and said that the army suddenly couldn’t take a vacation and would not be back until the next Sunday.

ami: pasowal sa ci mamo, "adihayay to ko mitangtangan, tahidangen to ko 'alomanay a mitahka."
english: Grandma said that she has cooked so much, so let’s eat together!

ami: matahidang to niyam ko salawinawina ato widawidang a malacecay a mitahka tona kadofahay a sakalafi.
english: We invited friends and family to have a great dinner together.

ami: iraay ko cecay a kapot ako ci Kacaw halitawalay cingra a mihawikid to kalimaamaan.
english: I have a classmate named Kacaw, he often forgets to bring things.

ami: to pinanaman i, micaliw cingra to impic, sararop anca o tilid no kapot.
english: During class, he borrowed pencils, erasers or notebooks from his classmates.

ami: kinacecay, kinatosa, kinatolo pacaliwan to no 'alomanay cingra to kalimaamaan.
english: Once, twice, three times, everyone would lend him something.

ami: nikawrira iraay koya tati'ihay a pinangan ningra, mafana'ay a micaliw, mafokilay a patikol.
english: But he has a bad habit of often borrowing things but not returning them.

ami: saikor to i, cowa to kakahi a pacaliw ko 'alomanay i cingranan.
english: In the end, no one wanted to borrow anything from him.

ami: yo cecay a romi'ad, mapolong kami a malacafay a misalama.
english: One day, we all went on an outing together.

ami: i fatad no lalan, ka'enihay ci Kacaw, nikawrira matawal ningra ko sa'ilos.
english: On the way, Kacaw wanted to go to the bathroom, but he forgot to bring toilet paper.

ami: micaliw cingra to sa'ilos i kapokapotan, cowa kapihawikid kako han no 'alomanay cingra a pasowal.
english: He borrowed toilet paper from his classmates, but everyone told him that I didn't bring them either.

ami: tangic sato ci Kacaw to caroh ningra. keter sa a somowal, "mana cowa kakahi kamo a pacaliw i takowanan to sa'ilos!"
english: Kacaw burst into tears. He said angrily, why don't everyone lend me toilet paper!

ami: pakafana' han no kapot cingra, cowa kapihawikid kiso to no miso, ya mipacaliwan i tisowanan a dafong i, cowa ho kapatikolen iso.
english: The classmate told him, because you didn't bring it yourself, and you wouldn't return the things lent to you!

ami: to roma sa to a romi'ad a mitilid, pacerem ci Kacaw a talapitilidan, ya micalwan ho ni Kacaw a dafong i, patikolen to ningra ko kapot.
english: The next day at school, Kacaw arrived at school early and returned everything he had borrowed from his classmates.

ami: ta'ong han to ni Kacaw ko kapokapot a pasowal, ikor to haw i, mihawikid to cingra to no niyah to a dafong, miaray aca cingra to pipacaliw no kapot i cingraan i 'ayaw.
english: kacaw apologized to the students and said that he would definitely bring his own things in the future, and thanked the classmates for their willingness to lend him things before.

ami: o mi'adopay a tamdaw ko wama ako.
english: My dad is a hunter of the tribe.

ami: yo kaemang ho kako, mihawikid ci ama aci faki to fonos ato kowang a malingad to dadaya.
english: When I was little, my dad and uncle would go out at night with hunting knives and guns.

ami: kanikaran to i, mapanokay to nangra ko tama' a minokay.
english: At daybreak, they returned with their prey.

ami: to roma i, o fafoy anca o lawal, latekay ira ko tolok.
english: Sometimes it was a boar, sometimes a flying squirrel, and occasionally a pheasant.

ami: misilsil cangra to tama' i 'adawang, palilamen nangra ko finawlan.
english: They would divide the prey at the entrance of the village and share it with the tribe.

ami: micaraan to ako ci ama, mi'ocil a malahakelong ci wamaan a mi'adop.
english: Every time I quarreled with my father, I wanted to go hunting with my father.

ami: ta'angay to kiso nga' keriden ako kiso sa ci ama i takowanan.
english: Dad said that he would take me with me when I grew up.

ami: to sakanga'ayaw no mako a mitoor to mato'asay a mi'adop, milisiw kako a misanga' to talakal , so'elin narikay a citama' to 'a'adopen ko talakal no mako.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practice making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

ami: paka'araw ci ama, sowal sa i takowanan, cowa kaeca o mamalasaidahiay a mi'adopay a tamdaw kiso sa.
english: Dad saw it and told me that I will be a very good hunter in the future.

ami: mato'as to kako, koyoden to ako ko focol ato pana' a mihakelong ci amaan a mi'adop.
english: In order to go hunting with adults as soon as possible, I practiced making traps every day, and soon my traps can really catch prey.

ami: ano patatikol to i niyaro' i, wapalilamen ko finawlan to tama' no pi'adop ako.
english: When returning to the village, share the hunted prey with the tribe.

ami: sowal sa ci ama, "kansiyaen ita ko palemed no to'as, adihay ko kinaira ita a mi'adop."
english: Dad said, we want to thank the ancestors for their blessings, so that we have a lot of prey to harvest.

ami: Maapac kako to dafak a talapitilidan.
english: I was late for school this morning.

ami: Matawal ako mihawikid to, kafang a talapitilidan.
english: When I was going to school, I forgot to bring my backpack.
I didn't bring anything with me.

ami: Misatapang to a minanam, malacafay a minengneng to codad kako ato kapot ako.
english: During class, I and my classmates read the textbook together.

ami: Misatapang to a miseking, pacaliw ko kapot to impic ato sararop i takowanan.
english: During the exam, a classmate lent me a pen and an eraser.

ami: Sowal sa ko singsi i takowanan "karatar to a lomowad, aka to kaapac!"
english: The teacher told me, Wake up earlier next time and don't be late again!""

ami: Sanga'ayay a widang ako ci Kacaw, o wawa no Pangcah cingra.
english: My good friend’s name is Kacaw, and he is also an Amis child.

ami: Malacafay kami a mitilid i Tafalong a niyaro'.
english: We study together in the Tafalong tribe.

ami: Pararid kami a malacecay mitengil to ko pikimad no mato'asay, tadamafana' to kami a caciyaw to sowal no Pangcah.
english: We often listen to the elders telling stories together, and we both can speak the Amis proficiently.

ami: Takaraw a masoeso kako, poener a makoli ci Kacaw.
english: I am tall and overweight, while Kacaw is short and thin.

ami: Tada tariktikay ci Kacaw, maolah kami cingraan a mapolong.
english: Kacaw is very energetic, and everyone likes him a lot.

ami: O piongtokay no pitilidan a romi'ad anini, adihay ko lalifeten no pitilidan.
english: Today was the school's sports day, and the school organized many competitions.

ami: Ira ko masasolotay, micokaray to mali, comikayay, masakeroay ato mipana'ay.
english: There were tug of war, soccer, running, dancing, and archery.
I participated in the running competition.

ami: Yo comikayay ho kako i, matolo'ay, mare:mesay ko tosor ako.
english: When I was running, I fell down, and my knees were bleeding.

ami: Na lomowad kako, lingatoen ako comikay a tala'ayaw.
english: But I stood up and continued running forward.

ami: Tahira to kako i pasetokan malipahak ko polong a maemin.
english: Everyone was happy when I reached the finish line.

ami: Talacowa awa maala ko sakacecay, nikaorira mahemekay to kako, hawhani malaheci to ako ko pilalifetan.
english: Although I didn't get first place, I'm glad because I completed the race.

ami: Talamiliso' ci fakian kako ato ci mama ako inacila.
english: Yesterday, my father and I visited my uncle.

ami: Pasowal sa cingra i tamiyanan, ma'epong ko fadahong no loma'.
english: He told us that there was a hole in the roof of his house.

ami: Misanga' ho cingra to fadahong i, nani fadahong a matefad.
english: He fell off the roof while repairing it.

ami: Mihawikid ci mama to titi no kolong ato 'icep a pafeli ci fakian.
english: My father brought beef and betel nuts for my uncle.

ami: Miholol kako ato ci faki i kafoti'an, adihay ko mipalada'an ningra a kimad.
english: My uncle and I chatted in the room, and he shared many stories.

ami: I'ayaw no piliyas ako, malata'ang ci faki i takowanan, takaraw to a tanektek to saan.
english: Before I left, my uncle praised me for growing taller and becoming more handsome.

ami: Sowal han nako "maadah to ko wa'ay ni faki, liyaw han tayni misalama i loma' niyam."
english: I said, When your foot gets better

ami: Itini i tosa patek tosa polo' ira ko tosa a mihecaan i, mikayki ko sifo to sakacipinang no tireng no Yin-co-min a manga'ay micidek to ngangan no finacadan a kayki.
english: In 2022, the government announced that indigenous identification cards can include tribal names separately.

ami: Milicay kako to matenesay misi'ayaway to sifo a milongoc to sakacipinang no tireng "micidek to ngangan no finacadan" a kapah no niyaro' ci Foting Mayaw.
english: I interviewed Foting Mayaw, a young tribal member who has long been advocating for the inclusion of tribal names on identification cards.

ami: Masasowal to kami a tayra i loma' ningra malalicay cingraan toni a pa'aliwacan.
english: We had arranged to visit his home this holiday for the interview.

ami: Malalicay ho i, pasifana'en ningra kako to na icowaay ko lalengawan no ngangan ningra, pasifana'en ningra kako to paro no loma' ningra, o niyaro' ningra.
english: During the interview, he introduced to me the origin of his name and also introduced me to his family and tribe.

ami: Licay han ako cingraan ano pacici han a mifalic to ngangan, tati'ih ko katelangay a pasingsi hayda?
english: I asked him why he insisted on changing his name. Wasn’t the old registration method sufficient?

ami: Sowal saan cingra i takowanan, nawhani o tilid no holam caay ka polita a pakafana' to ngangan ningra, maceli' ho no roma a tamdaw cingraan ci Fo先生 sanay, orasaka ira to ko adihayay a tatawaen masadak.
english: He told me that using Chinese characters could not accurately convey his name, and others would still call him \Fu Xian Sheng

ami: Sowal sa ci Foting Mayaw, "o tilid no sowal no Yin-co-min a ngangan i, o tadaso'elinay a ngangan no mita. O ngangan no mako i, o citodongay to finacadan no mita, laloma'an no mita, pinangan no tireng no mita, nanay ira ko 'aloman a 'aloman ko finawlan manga'ay patatikol to ngangan no niyah."
english: Foting Mayaw said, \The names written in indigenous languages are our true names. My name represents our ethnic group

ami: Mitoor kako ci amaan inacila tayra i icifa a pa'aca, adihay ko mihawikidan mipalomaan ni ama to dateng a tayra, ira ko misanga'an kaeso'ay a kakaenen no Pangcah a pafeli to 'alomanay.
english: Yesterday, I went to the market with my grandmother to set up a stall. My grandmother brought a lot of vegetables that she grew herself and also prepared indigenous cuisine for everyone.

ami: Maolah ko polong to pipa'acaan ni ama, 'aloman ko mi'acaay to damdam ato kakorot, 'aloman ko tayniay mitanam to mitangtangan ningra a kakaenen.
english: Everyone loved my grandmother's stall. Many people bought the chilis and African eggplants, and many people came to taste the dishes she cooked.

ami: Tadakaeso'ay ko mitangtangan ningra to lokot ato hakhak, ira ho ko mapacamolay to linnalo a kohaw no tefo', masolot no sanek ko 'alomanay a lafang, misarayaray to polong a tayni i pipa'acaan niyam.
english: The ferns and sticky rice she cooked were delicious, as well as the braised pork with maqaw pepper and wild boar meat. The flavors attracted many customers, and everyone lined up at our stall.

ami: Mitangtang ho ci ama i, miholol kako to lafang i tatihi. 'ang'ang han ako i tatihi "o mipalomaan niyam ko dateng, awaay ko sapaiyo, kalamkamen a tayni mi'aca yo!"
english: While my grandmother was cooking, I was on the side attracting customers. I shouted, The vegetables are self-grown

ami: Harakat a maemin mapa'aca ko papa'acaen niyam, sowal sa ci ama "nanay saheto kiso iraay ho ko pipadang."
english: Our goods sold out quickly, and my grandmother said, It's all thanks to your help.""

ami: Oni a demak i, mafana' to kako to nai pinalengaw no Yin-co-min ato kakaenen a fenek, roma sato matinako to ko roray no mipa'acaay.
english: Through this event, I learned about indigenous plants and food and experienced the hard work of running a stall.

ami: Ma'araw ko kinaolah ni ama to nai litengay a kakaenen, tada malata'ang ato mahemek ko faloco' ako.
english: Seeing my grandmother's passion for traditional food, I feel very proud and honored.

ami: tosa a polo' ira ko cacay
tosa a polo' ira ko tosa
tosa a polo' ira ko tolo
tosa a polo' ira ko sepat
tosa a polo' ira ko lima
tolo a polo' ira ko cacay

at the foot of the mountain
